Zoos have research programs that help expand our knowledge about animals, especially the endangered species. The information gained by these programs can help protect, and treat the species in the wild, as well as determine what affects if any climate change may have on the regions needed for the species to flourish. Many zoos also have breeding programs for all kinds of species, endangered or not, and learn even more about the species during the breeding, and rearing process. All this knowledge and information is shared with visitors, organizations, and other programs alike. There are certainly zoos that do nothing but display animals, but so many have broadened their exhibit goals, and expanded their species scope of responsibility, that each zoo really needs to be judged on it's own merits. Oh no! I am shocked and appalled. This is horrifying in terms of animal welfare. I just watched Meg 2 in movie theaters. The beggining of the movie depics a megladon shatk in a tank. It escapes shortly afterward. I think that is a bad idea. Sharks seem too active to do well in captivity. The closest real life parrellel is having a great white shark in captivity. I was curious on how that would work. This video confirmed my suspicians. It even shows that things are even worse than I thought.  One good parellel to the great white shark is the orca. They have a lot of superficial similarities. They do look very similar. They have the same basic lifestyle. Both are apex predators. Both are crusers in the open ocean. I Googled both animals. I found that both have phenominal endurance. They swim tens of miles every day. This video even shows specific animals in the diet in a great white shark. The adult diet has stuff that an orca would totally eat. There is a big diffence in terms classification though. Sharks belong in a primitive offshoot of vertibrites. This group is called chrondoicthys. This group also has rays and ratfish. Orcas are mammals instead. They are also very intellegent and social. These features make orcas similar to humans. So some anthropomorphizing of orcas is appropriate. It is cool that such distantly related animals can seem so similar. This is called convergent evolution. It blows my mind. My favorite example is actually sharks, dolphins and icthosaurs. Orcas fit in there too. They are essentially giant dolphins that have become apex predaters. Ray finned fish have thier own versions, which are tuna and swordfish.

Since we humans are a highly evolved species with huge advantages and advances over the rest, it is our ethical duty to respect and help other species even if it's as simple as not disturbing their peace and leaving them alone. Those who have devoted their life to study marine biology should be at the forefront of protecting this ethical boundary instead of being the ones putting them in aquariums and theme parks with the excuse to study them. And on that note, same goes  for dolphins and whales. Stop eating octopus and squid, there is tuna and many other alternatives. Actually, zoos were originally from the collections of the rich, who had a myriad of exotic animals either purchased or given to them as gifts. Some of them decided to start charging for folks to come see their collections of animals. Only later on would zoos start to focus more on research, rehab, and education. This doesn't mean zoos are without their problems. The majority of zoos are private, roadside entertainment venues owned by people who have no experience caring for animals. Not only that, but studies have shown that even the best of zoos don't contribute to the global protection of animals as much as they would like to brag. Much of the research has to do with how to keep the animals alive in captivity, the majority of the animals cannot be released into the wild, and many zoos still source their animals from the wild through cruel and inhumane methods.   Just seeing an animal doesn't mean you someone become educated by it, or even inspired to do something for those animals. Most people go to a zoo or aquarium for a fun day out. It's entertainment.

I think you have to be really careful lumping all zoos together. I used to work at one, and everyone I worked with considered animal well being to be the number one priority, with the number two priority being conservation and all the efforts that are being done to increase wild populations.

Many zoos also have breeding programs for all kinds of species, endangered or not, and learn even more about the species during the breeding, and rearing process. Zoos have research programs that help expand our knowledge about animals, especially theÂ endangered species. The information gained by these programs can help protect, and treat the species in the wild, as well as determine what affects if any climate change may have on the regions needed for the species to flourish. Many zoos also have breeding programs for all kinds of species, endangered or not, and learn even more about the species during the breeding, and rearing process. All this knowledge and information is shared with visitors, organizations, and other programs alike. There are certainly zoos that do nothing but display animals, but so many have broadened their exhibit goals, and expanded their species scope of responsibility, that each zoo really needs to be judged on it's own merits. i suspect part of the problem is sleep,  great whites sleep by essentially gliding to the bottom of the ocean in 15 minute catnaps.  to do this they need deep unobstructed water that runs straight and clear for long distances, furthermore, while the shark itself is warm blooded in comparison to most shark species which allows it to be much more active and fast for sustained periods of time, it is believed that they use deep cold water to lower their own metabolism naturally when they're not in an ideal hunting environment.  by keeping these sharks in a shallow puddle of water they're denying them rest and likely artificially increasing their metabolism in an environment they can't get enough food to eat.  frankly they probably aren't even in the mood to eat, in shallow warm water with no real sources of food, no way to sleep, and no escape, i can imagine the stress is unlike anything an animal like that usually experiences even in the harsh competitive environments of the ocean.

Reputable zoos work toward the conservation and protection of species and education of the public. For the animals, the focus is on providing nutritionally-balanced diets that meet their needs; enrichment to keep them mentally and physically stimulated and occupied; meeting their social needs; enclosures that resemble their natural habitats while also allowing visitors an opportunity to view them (and places to hide from visitors if/when they want to). The days of concrete and steel bars and the mindset of the zoo as entertainment are in the past.  Zoos are modern Noah's Arks, serving as ports in a storm for so many species. The habitats of thousands of species have been encroached on to the point that there's very limited space for the animals that are in the wild, never mind the ones in zoos, and wild numbers are declining alarmingly, and the threat of poaching is a threat to species around the world. There are more tigers in captivity (zoos and others) than there are in the wild. U.S. zoos that belong to the American Zoo and Aquarium Ass'n (AZA) have many programs in place for population and species management to increase populations of threatened and endangered species--I've assisted with the Wyoming Toad breeding program. The AZA also tightly controls (with the animals it's possible to control reproduction with, like the big cats) what animals are giving birth and when, so every baby born will have a home to go to.

There are actually a few advantages of having a system (that works to a reasonable degree) to care for an animal in captivity that donâ€™t even include research. Many zoos and aquariums have 3 functions; to educate and entertain the public, for research, and to house and rehabilitate wildlife that for one reason or another need to be protected. I donâ€™t think it is a bad idea to try to find a way that is healthy and safe to keep a great white shark in captivity for many reasons. But the facts may be that there just isnâ€™t a way to make it healthy or safe. And the unfortunate truth is that more than likely the previous attempts to contain the great white were more inspired by greed than anything else. Not to mention the lives lost in these attempts is not only heartbreaking, but just not worth the cost.

I do think that there was definitley money driving the whole operation. But i also think that it could have been part of a conservation effort, as bizarre and convoluted as it may seem. During the 80s and 90s, a lot of people were deathy afraid of great whites from their media portrayals (jaws, surf movies, ect), and didnt really care if they went extinct or not. But by seeing a great white shark in captivity,and showcasing the things that make it such a unique creature, it could have been an effort to introduce sharks as peaceful creatures to a general audience. If more people could see these magnificent creatures as more than bloodthirsty killers, then more people would care about poachers driving the species to extinction. Using the sharks as a way to dissolve misinformation. I in no way agree with the captivation of sharks if it harms them, and especially in situations like this one, but i can see the intent behind it.

I see a lot of comments talking about how aquariums and zoos are places of abuse for animals. As a museum studies student, Iâ€™d like to discuss this a little bit.  In the late 18 to early 1900â€™s, there were a number of humans kept in â€œmuseums.â€ Iâ€™m not talking sideshows, or freak shows. No, not that. There were people like Ota Benga kept alive in mainstream places like the Bronx Zoo, held there as if they were animals to be observed. His story is terrifying, but there are others as well.   To come out and say that all aquariums and zoos treat animals unfairly or poorly is not only overlooking the stories of people like Ota Benga, but itâ€™s also ignoring the fact that a majority of these institutions have vast conservation programs, veterinary programs, and research labs to protect these species. A lot of animals kept in these institutions may not be able to survive in the wild, and to research them on a daily basis on a close scale can actually improve our knowledge of the species and aid in conservation efforts beyond the tank.   Yes, of course there are issues with captivity. But making this a black and white â€œall bad all goodâ€ argument about museum practices simply isnâ€™t justified, especially if one is unaware of the history of these kinds of institutions.

Of course there is no true good or true evil when it comes to zoo's and aquariums, but that doesn't mean they can't improve. There is a lot of questionability about how much people actually learn from these facilities, especially since the higher quality zoos and aquariums are the minority. Most facilities are small, private, roadside zoos with at best questionable ethics and the treatment of their animals. Even in the high quality zoos information might be old, outdated, or simply not read. Studies have shown that the average zoo visitor spends less than a minute observing a display, even with the most popular animals like elephants. Some facilities even missinform the public, skewing data in order to make captivity seem more appealing. For example, SeaWorld has missinformed the public for decades about the lifespan of Orca, insisting that it was 25-30 years. Similarly, many facilities will try to downplay the average lifespan of Belugas and bottlenose dolphins, making it appear that they live as long in captivity as they do in the wild.   And yes, while many zoos and aquariums have breeding and conservation programs, studies have found that when compared to the profit these facilities make, their efforts fall quite short. An observation of the Vancouver Aquarius conservation budge saw a continual decrease in the late 2000's.Then there is the breeding of animals that, by the own word of zoos and aquariums, cannot be released into the wild. Polar Bears, Elephants, Orca, Tigers and Lions are just a few of the many animal species that are bred that have no conservation value.  The problem with zoos and aquariums comes from the fact that they are holding living, breathing, thinking, feeling creatures in spaces often far too small for them and without enough mental stimulation. t would be nice to see these facilities stop breeding the animals that cannot be released and start focusing more on their actual conservation efforts and local problems. A person doesn't need to have a tiger pacing in front of them in order to appreciate them either. The technology we have today can bring people close to animals without taking them out of their natural environment, and can give people a better idea of what these animals are actually like, vs the unnatural behaviors they'll see in a zoo or aquarium.

This video missed Steinhart aquarium's explanation WHY sharks kept bumping into the aquarium walls. Sharks have electromagnetic sensors sensitive enough to detect muscle movement of prey. Â @Amy_the_LizardÂ  There's obviously a world of difference between dogs and white sharks though. Domesticated animals have gone through literally thousands of years of human-controlled selective breeding to make them better suited to being domesticated, making them friendlier and often smaller, more docile and easier to tame. Even less intensely breed creatures that we have as pets like various lizards and birds are smaller and easier to take care of, yet a lot can go wrong with them too. In fact essentially all domesticated creatures can still massively suffer mental and physical issues from improper care. The only exception probably being like, insects. So imagine trying to adapt a great white shark, even a relatively small or young one, to living in captivity in a small environment, after being corralled and transported which is often a hugely stressful thing for them. The whole process is an absolute nightmare for those sharks, they're massive, incredibly powerful creatures, it would take centuries of breeding to get them anywhere near naturally ready to live in such small, controlled environment, by then they'd have to be much dumber and docile, it really isn't worth it.

Â @goten339Â  I wasn't saying that it wasn't horrible for the sharks, nor was I denying that animal abuse happens - obviously the animals being abused or improperly cared for are miserable. The Monterey Bay Aquarium has several running conservation programs, such as their sea otter program were orphaned baby otters are raised by foster mom otters and released back into the wild, greatly contributing to the rising sea otter numbers in California. Thereâ€™s several exhibits dedicated to showing the effect overfishing and pollution has on the world and what we can do to fix it, and the animals in there care that can do well in a tank environment are well cared for. Great white Sharks are creatures that need the open ocean, and after several attempts the aquarium stopped the program that was leading to the deaths of these animals. The whole point of doing it in the first place was so that the public could see what amazing animals they are, since their is still a deep general fear of sharks in the public, especially great whites, which has directly contributed to their declining numbers. Some animals wonâ€™t do well in an aquarium environment, but that should not mean ignoring the immense amount of good the aquarium does for the species it can help.

It seems like sharks which are pelagic, fast-swimming and obligate ram ventilators don't do well in captivity. I understand that these kinds of sharks might have to be held in tanks for research purposes (this could including research on how to extend their lifespans in captivity), but I don't think we should keep them for entertainment/display purposes until new technology is developed which makes it easier for them to live comfortably in captivity. While the sentiment of these comments is really admirable there is a scary amount of misinformation being spread. Everyone needs to remain wary of zoos and aquariums that take poor care of their animals and exhibit animal cruelty. These places are becoming less common in developed countries and they are normally smaller family run businesses, hobby farms, tourist trap amusement parks. However! There are still many zoos and aquariums that adhere to strict standards and employ only professionals who care about each animal's comfort and happiness deeply. And you cannot turn your back on them because these places are some of the few organisations that make real difference in conservation. These places bring animals back from the brink of extinction with rehabilitation, breeding programs, and releasing and monitoring new populations back into the wild. They also put big money and resources behind environmentalist legislation and habitat protection.  A lot of these comments also really discount the value of learning about these animals first hand. "I don't need to see a great white. let it be free!" While yes I agree that I hope aquariums stop trying with great whites, since it's clearly not going to work, you're really not seeing the big picture when you villainize these researchers. 100 million sharks are killed each year and the only way to stop that is to spread awareness, change public perception so that laws and fishing practices can change. Monteray Bay Aquarium kept 6 great whites since 2004 and while this video focused on the one that died the others were released back into the wild alive, and each monitored for a month. MB Aquarium also allows approximately 75,000 students a year to explore the aquarium for free. The movie Jaws did irreparable damage to the public perception of sharks resulting in decades of culling across the world and it really is vitally important that people see 'scary animals' in real life and appreciate for themselves how beautiful and special they are, so that they will put their support behind the fight for their futures.

It was a success within the context of increasing the shark's lifepspan in captivity.  It was awful that the shark died, but you can't deny that they succeeded in extending its life compared to similar sharks in the past.  It seems like people won't stop capturing these sharks, so even if you don't think we should put them on display, it is probably a good idea to research how we can extend their lives in captivity.  I agree that at the time being it is cruel and wasteful to keep these sharks in aquariums to entertain the public, but we can't make any progress without research and it doesn't seem like people will stop demanding that these sharks eventually be put into aquariums for long time periods.  We should do more research and see if it is possible, at least so we can prove that they absolutely can't live in tanks for long periods when people complain about it, (even though there is lots of evidence as to why they can't live in tanks already, some people will not be satisfied until more comes out).
because its 6 days compared to 6 months... and it lived after captivity. thats a sucsess.

Being able to hold animals in captivity is crucial if we want to continue to study them, and be able to understand the creature and really our world. It becomes really expensive to study things in the open ocean and you can't really test certain things out there. Without this knowledge, we wouldn't know half of what we know about our oceans today, simply from analyzing animals in captivity. It was a success because every other shark died within the week, this made it to 6 months which was amazing for any researcher that wanted to get up close and personal. Now we are able to understand how much more of an impact we have on the ocean if keeping great whites in anything under 4 million gallons already creates problems.

Â @stezzytatoÂ  I've been in zoos that did a fantastic job with the enclosures. They were huge and full of vegetation and hiding places and the animals seemed happy (there was none of the typical pacing back and forth etc, but instead they were all minding their own business, chilling, grazing, playing) Zoos are for education and preserving wildlife and I want the people that don't have enough money to travel to the animals (tourism would destroy more of their habitat anyways) to have a chance to see them and to be able to learn.  Note that I do condemn zoos with inadequate enclosures (worked in one before and it was heartbreaking) and private people having exotic pets (especially tigers and bears etc)  So all in all I do prefer animals living in the wild, but as long as they have the space I think zoos are not too bad.

To the people saying donâ€™t capture animals for zoos and aquariums, keep this in mind.  Entertainment is not the only reason they do this.  Often it is to educate the general public or protect species.  People get more interested in protecting marine life thanks to aquariums.  They also keep some species alive.  The Georgia aquarium has a species of coral that is fully extinct in the wild.  They plan to reintroduce it once they find a polyp that can survive warmer waters to account for ocean warming.

to people saying "stop imprisoning living creatures for human entertainment":   aquariums actually benefit most animals since the monitored environments aren't polluted like the natural environments of these creatures. the pollution that the human race has stressed upon the earth's sea won't be reversed any time soon, so putting the creatures in aquariums protects them from the hazards of pollution in their natural habitat. not only that but there is a less risk of them going extinct because (1) they don't have to experience the threat on invasive species killing them off in their natural habitat and (2) humans can't over-hunt or over-fish. yes the aquariums do entertain humans but they also in turn benefit the animals. i completely agree that animals and living creatures deserve freedom and shouldn't be treated as slaves to entertain humans, but in this case, aquariums and conservation programs protect these creatures rather enslave while in turn giving humans the joy of observing the various life forms around us.  AND YEA OF COURSE, if aquariums are harmful to creatures such as the great white then um I HIGHLY recommend KEEPING them in their natural habitat.  **edit: take this with a grain of salt, lol im 15, what do i know about this kinda stuff? this is just my opinion from an outside perspective but correct me if im wrong about anything or drop some knowledge in the replies, i have nothing against learning  more :)

Sharks like the nursing shark, tiger, and even lemon sharks etc, can be put into captivity becuase they tend to have typical migration patterns along coastal areas, meaning it's easier to simulate their living environments (even the whale shark, but those also tend to stay in very shallow, heated waters). However, mako, Great White, and Hammer head sharks, all swim openly out at sea with the ability to travel as they please. You can't replicate those conditions in any tank, and even if the tank is suitable enough, the shark will not be able to stay confined with becoming literally depressed, and dieing.

A lot of people in this comments section are trying their best to virtue signal without even understanding the issue here. No, it's not enough to just 'leave them where they are'.  How do you think conservation science works? That we rock up to an endangered animal one day and put it into a reserve and that's that? It takes years, sometimes decades of research to understand how to keep a wild animal in captivity, alive, healthy and breeding. Predatory fish are killed on sight by fishermen and others to protect their hauls or themselves- great whites themselves are on the threatened list now. If they dwindle to near-extinction, how exactly do you idiots propose we breed them in captivity if no one knows how to keep them alive?  Second, it IS important people see animals and organisms that they otherwise couldn't. Not everyone has the money to pay for a trip of the ocean to see ocean fauna in their natural habitat. The more people lose the ability to relate to an animal, the less the public and policymakers will care about keeping these species from going extinct. Not to mention we'd be raising an entire generation of kids with no awareness of these creatures besides stuff they see in books or on TV/the internet. There are zoos and aquariums with horrible records, piss poor conditions and a complete lack of scientists among the staff, but to assume every zoo and aquarium is like that tells me maybe you should visit a proper one before you go rushing into conclusions.  So while you lot try and out-PETA each other here, spare a thought that what's going on may be beyond your elementary school-level understanding of the world.

I'm not a scientist, but even I know why the sharks die in captivity.  Sharks, being apex predators, are extremely sensitive and when they're in captivity their environment is so abnormal that it causes extreme stress which takes a heavy and severe physiological toll on their bodies, which would eventually lead to organ complications ultimately resulting in their deaths. I wonder, what if they were to use very high powered pumps around the edges of a tank. I don't think they would be able to get the water to move inwards toward the center of the tank, as you could only place the pumps on the top or bottom. Placing them directly on the side of a tank would essentially prevent it from being viewable.   But if they placed strong pumps all around the top of the tank, I wonder if the shark could learn. If the entire tank was glass, and looked essentially like endless ocean, I wonder if it could work. That would give the shark a pseudo feeling of freedom, and sense of comfort. And he might be able to learn the ques from being forced downward when he reaches the side.   I have no idea if this would work or not, it is just a thought. Also, I wonder if they have ever tried to raise a White Shark in a tank environment from birth. That definitely has its own completely new challenges. But if they can keep a small yearling for 6 months, perhaps they could improve and bring in a pregnant shark about to give birth. As soon as she does, remove the mother and any other offspring from the tank.  Sharks don't rear their young, so the babies are largely living off instinct. That seems to not be a great indicator of success, but it also means that they don't have to keep both a baby and a mother alive together.

Granted, I can see y'all point saying it's kinda cruel and detrimental to keep killing these increasingly rare animals trying to keep them, but there's a reason behind the madness.  First, research. It's a lot easier to study an animal in captivity, as you have 24 hr access that's not hampered by weather, hazards, or...not being able to find a freaking shark (big ocean you know).  Two, conservation. Yes, it sounds ass backwards killing an animal to save it, but they were trying to see if they could keep a shark in a secure location, safe from illegal fishing where-maybe-they could breed it.    It's a pity they weren't able to keep it though. Perhaps in the future we'll figure out a better solution that'll help further these goals. For now, hope we can save the enviroment it's living in and crack down on the fin trade.

They're just not meant for being in captivity. I understand the curiosity and awe of wanting to see them, be near them, experience a live great white up close: They're seriously awe-inspiring animals, modern day prehistoric giant predators that live right out in the silent, deep, wide open ocean... It's fascinating. But human fascination isn't a good reason to keep capturing and killing animals. That's like a little kid who hurts the pet cat because it's curious about cats. I know that more sharks are killed by fishing trawlers, for food, or in shark culls than in any of these aquariums, but it's still unnecessary (and so are those other things). Scientific curiosity and research is one thing, and I'm glad that these attempts at least lead to more knowledge and understanding about these sharks, but they just don't belong up here, on land, in a tank inside a building, bumping into walls getting distressed while people gawk. I'm glad they stopped the program. Leave the sharks in the ocean, we share a planet but have completely different worlds. They don't belong in ours.

I was there at the MBA as a student guide during 2004 when they were displaying the White. Vox is missing a key component of why Great Whites in particular are so damn hard to keep alive in captivity, as opposed to say, hammerheads, another deep sea shark that while difficult, is kept alive quite frequently. Great Whites hunt with a finely tuned system that sends out some sort of pulse into the environment. Great whites kept detecting the generator that was being used in exhibits such as the Outer Bay, (where they kept the one they finally got to work), and it was literally sending the sharks into seizures. It's why the MBA gave up on keeping whites, it was simply too hard to adjust everything in the environment for them. Plus, ofc, the one they had in 2004 tore into a tuna also in the exhibit right in front of a guide explaining how these creatures are so misunderstood, lol.

â€‹Â @GhettojakuÂ  On average, about 6,500 people die on an hourly basis - for any reason. We aren't extinct yet.. And if we were to go extinct based solely on deaths per hour and no new children were born, it would take about 132 years before we went extinct.  But the hourly birth rate is ~15.000. Almost 3 times the number of deaths we have an hour - meaning that in ~58 years we should be about 15 billion people. This isn't incorporating all factors that we know of, of course but given this, it's easy to extrapolate from this line of thinking to sharks.   Sharks don't breed as much as we do - but they do breed - and there is no certain estimate of how many sharks are in the ocean, but I would estimate myself that there is at least several billion sharks across all shark species. If we estimate that in 1950 there were 10 billion sharks across all species and they bred at a quarter of the speed of humans, meaning they would make an additional 5k every hour.  If we take the IFLS estimate of 11,5k shark killings an hour the number would decline by 6,5k every hour. How long would it take for it to go extinct? More than 175 years. Someone could easily do better math than I could and probably some time in the future scientists can more easily make estimates of how many sharks are alive in the world. Great white sharks have senses and abilities that humans and a lot of sharks don't have. These abilties help the shark hunt and well... Navigate the ocean because that's what great whites do. They travel. They travel for miles upon miles. They go to mating areas and  hunting areas generally staying near the coast but not in a shallow reef area altho they can travel as shallow as they are tall from stomach to back. The reason they don't generaly hang in these shallow areas is because there hunting tactics is to attack something from above from a great length below using the vertical distance to gain speed. So there hunting abilities really on a large area of vertical room. Us humans have are basic 5 senses that everybody talks about. Sight, touch, hearing, taste, and smell. But imagine if we spent all our life in a world completely differant. Where our form of seeing was murky and to eat we had to find our food in a one colored sea with a lot of that food being colored like the ocean or rocks. Well the sight thing won't get you too far. So ovecorce we would need to fall back on those other senses. While sharks do have sight they have a multitude of other abilitys that are very useful. Have you ever heard the saying "a shark can smell a drop of blood from a mile away"? Well that may be an exaduration to some extent but it is true that sharks are very good at finding blood and injured fish that are easy pray. Great white sharks also have the ability to sence magnetic fields. Thats why magnetic shark repelants works. They can feel very very slight activities in the water that can tell them where activity is. And these are only the  surface of all shark abilities. But when you put all this together you have a shark that has a map of the ocean and what is happening around the ocean in the white sharks head. This is how they are able to travel all over and still find breeding and feeding areas. That's what makes this shark so amazing. Some sharks hang out in the reafs. Some sharks near shores feeding on fish and birds that fly near the water. Some behemoth sharks swim in the depths of the ocean feeding on large amounts of plankton and other small sea life. Some even live in the deepest places amagionable under great amounts of pressure and heat. Some live on the bottom of the sea, on top of rocks, blending in with sea bed until a fish swims over it. Some, like the great white, travel long distances as do some forms of the hammerhead but they travel in schools that are formed a lot like the geese we see on land. But the great white has no bounderies or limits the thing about the great white. Its a lone adventurer that goes anywhere it wants when it wants to. One shark could travel all over the world by themselves. That's why they have all these abilities because that's just how they work and live. So when you take one and put it in a tank its like doing the following to a human. Imagine if you were just walking down the street and all of a sudden your blind, deaf, and have almost no senses at all the ones you do still have tell you you've been put in a completely new environment. Even the air your breathing has been changed and feels differant. So you try to move. Nomater what way you go you always bump into a wall within a few feet. You don't know how to eat anymore. And Ofcorce there's no one there to teach you! There's food present but you can't eat it because the old way you ate food doesn't work anymore. You had no warning you just were there. Had all your world suddenly disappear. How long do you think you would survive?

The Outer Bay exhibit, which is where the great white was kept in the Monterey Bay Aquarium, had its glass created by a Japanese company that was so secretive on how they did it, that they shut down the entire area while they installed the glass. Even MBA employees were kept out. Nothing short of a wrecking ball could have taken that glass out- plus there were 11 layers to it, a crack in one layer would do absolutely nothing to the other 10.  Source- Me, I was there in 2004 when they had this white on display as a student guide, they told us a lot of this because guests would ask us these questions. And "Can she break the glass?" was definitely one of my top-three questions I had about her while working there.

by making an aquarium seperated from outside water sources you are able to elimenate natural disasters such as red tide or el nino. as red tide is extremely poisinous to over 75% of all aquatic life, and rapid heating or cooling of the waters near that region can also kill thousands of fish. even if you seperated the waters with glass it would still take 5-10 times for power to keep the water at the proper temperature than to just seperate it completely.

@Hank Hodges, we dont just put the animals up for display for people to gawk at. The aquariums usually have influences from colleges and think tanks that help fund the expeditions so that they can study the creatures and figure out how they live their lives.  By being able to observe 1 or 2 of them for a couple of years we may be able to figure out how sharks and whales are able to combat issues like cancer and slow and eventually get rid of it. If we can figure out how they do it then we stand a chance of finding a cure ourselves, while also being able to cure the creatures as well in the mean time. These places invest 3-4 million dollars just to get one shark into the tank not to mention the construction price for the exhibit and the tank, crew, specialists. But they may only see 100k return from admission fees to the park. We dont bring them in just to make money, and even an idiot can tell you thats a horrible investment. @Strawberry Flavored Clorox Bleach | Listen, I'm gonna give you why you, sir, can't kill them. It's called a food chain. You kill the animal at the top (which in 2 thirds of the ocean is a shark), say A, the creature below it, say B, has a population boom. Because of which, the prey of B, say C, is eaten into oblivion. Because of which B will no longer have food, i.e. it will too die. Basically, you remove a shark, lion, wolf, or any other apex predator, and the ecology goes to hell.   Why do the other animals matter??? Say the fish at the bottom of the food chain goes extinct. The algae or plankton or zooplankton it fed on, would boom. Green plant infested slimy beaches.  We have no idea how, or whether if, the ocean can deal with the extinction of sharks. Considering sharks take a long time to grow and reproduce. Making them go extinct is much easier (though not easy) than you think. And that, sir, is why you can't kill a species off. Any species! Be it mosquitoes, sharks, or rodents.   Check this video. And don't mind the start. Please. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tAzxkDQFPe0

Great video and very informative - although very sad!  So sad to see this happen to such majestic creatures. We are based in Hermanus, South Africa (about an hour and a half's drive from Cape Town), known as the whale watching capital of the world. One hour's drive from Hermanus is a small fishers' village, Gansbaai (directly translation: Goose Bay) that is a known for Great White shark cage diving.   Gansbaai is situated at the one end of Walker Bay, the bay having shallow water with Hermanus basically in the middle of the bay's shore. This is one of the reasons that the Southern Right whales are so prominent in this bay: mating, giving and raising their calves, sometimes getting as close as 5 meters (16.4 ft) from certain shores.   You never get sharks in the bay, as they HATE the shallower water, even though there is an overflow of food for them from seals, and penguins. Go to Gansbaai at the end of the bay and there is a great number of Great White sharks with the water being much deeper there than in the Walker bay area. There is the odd shark that wonders off, but that doesn't happen often, mostly off track being lured by cage diving boats.

Hmmm, I think you are looking at it wrong. Although a lot of your points make sense, don't forget that its not the same thing to watch an animal on a funny video online than actually seeing it. The first time I went to the zoo I was amazed by the animals and a feeling of protecting them and know more about them grew inside me. Its not the same as a Shelter, were you dont really good to experience the animals and seeing them "as if" they were out in the wild. Aquariums and zoos are great at creating awareness of the animal kingdom and talk about our responsibility to protect them. In fact, most aquariums and Zoos tell you about endangered species and how humans have destroyed their habitats, making you feel like we should stop that.   And talking about zoos as if they were enslavers is kinda dumb. Sure, I guess not everyone that works in one is a selfless person but the experts that take care of the animals usually love them a lot and really look after their well being. After all, they are experts cuz they studied about those animals because they really want the best for them since they were kids.   I know its cool to go all Green and stuff, and its awesome that you care, but acting like you know better than the experts is just kinda dumb. Comparing this to "killing homosexuals" or whatever, doesn't really apply. You could be keywarrioring all you want on the Internet, but usually the people working on this places are the ones actually taking care of the animals.  There's an awesome video of Adam Ruins Everything about the Safari Zones that explains further all the things to consider when talking about this topics and how even something as conterintuitive as letting people hunt animals to protect them is actually a great idea.  If I sounded mean in anyway, just want you to know I did not meant it. an adult great white could be kept in an aquarium only if that aquarium decided to make its tank the size of about 4-5 football fields combined. then also have it about 50 meters deep. the reason for this is great whites are known to swim long distances in one direction without turning. With that vast open space, an adult great white could survive. Only problem is, that tank is bigger than most aquariums themselves. you would also have to constantly have other fish in there with it as great whites are hunters and they need to catch their prey and not be fed out of a big bucket. you could even enduce a small current in the tank to simulate open ocean currents. So long story short it can be done but the money it would cost to effectively do it isnt worth it at all.

This is surprisingly easy to fix, and I'm disturbed that Aquariums never figured it out, or they decided it wasn't financially worth it? Like how the glass of your car has sheets of plastic in-between the layers to prevent it from shattering, Sharks like Great Whites navigate with extreme electrical sensitivity at the snout, so if a layer of thin net-like metallic film was layered inside the glass, the Shark would never bump into it because it would be able to detect the weak electrical current pumped through it, and so avoid it altogether, and if the Aquarium was Donut-Shaped, it would swim in a circle endlessly, clear of the glass walls. On top of this, Great White Sharks are long-ranging pack hunters, opposite like Killer Whales which are close-ranging pack hunters, and require Social Interaction from their species, and so an Isolated Individual will experience Psychological Trauma in an Aquarium Setting, thus a collective of Donut-Tanks connected to one another for multiple sharks is required. You can't own just one Great White, you need a Breeding Colony of at least 3 Males and 5 Females I would imagine, and the overall size of the exhibit would fit a small zoo all its own? This kind of project would be ambitious, even if a Billionaire City like Abu Dhabi attempted it!

With exceptions, most major Aquariums in the developed world are places where scientists and vets carefully care for, monitor and study a select population sample of animals so that we can learn how to better protect their habitats and coexist with other animals, etc. While children and dummies may miss this point when visiting aquariums, it should be fairly obvious to all others that the purpose of these exhibits is to highlight and convey the results of this research, not just for the animals to "be on display" for the visitors.  Its not as simple humans "just leaving animals alone."  Of course those who mistreat and abuse animals (i.e., Sea World) should be condemned and shut down. But aquariums attached to properly funded scientific research projects are important. Those of you who are upset because they saw Finding Dory too many times need to look at the bigger picture.

They're not fragile - we just keep displaying them in bathtubs. Look at a satellite picture of SeaWorld. You can actually see the great dark bodies of the orcas (killer whales) - and be horrified to observe that even the biggest tanks don't give them room for a good swim, let alone 100 miles per day. In 1961, the first captive orca, Wanda, lasted 3 days. It was over two decades before a captive killer whale was able to give birth to an infant that survived 30 days (1985).     One of the saddest phrases for any animal on display is "doesn't breed well in captivity." Organizations are finally coming to grips with the problem. SeaWorld has finally agreed to stop breeding orcas. Many american zoos are getting out of the elephant business. Ringling Brothers retired their elephants!! That made me so happy!    Granted, animals are losing habitat in the wild. But people are trying to do more for animals, to prevent poaching ivory and unnecessary deaths. All we can do is try to do better, because our zoos are not going to "save" these particular species by breeding them.

If sharks were to go extinct, since they are at the top of the food chain, then it would lead to more food(the food that sharks used to eat, that now is uneaten and propering even more), the ecoystem would not be disrupted at all, only if a vital conmponent such as plancton was removed, then the entire marine life could go extinct, for reference, plancton is the food that many of the tiny fishes eat (at the bottom of the food chain).   My point is that if you remove a bottom of the food chain species, it would lead to a lot more trouble than if you remove a top of the food chain predator, the same could be said for the extinction of humans, the world would be better off without them, (except for domesticated animals), and not putting to account that if humans were to go extinct all of a sudden, thousands of factories, nuclear plants and other facilities would be in imminent danger towards the environment, but that's another story.

You'd think that, but predators are actually rather key to many ecosystems.  One of the most famous examples was reintroducing wolves to Yellowstone, which totally altered the local and regional environments arguably for the better.  Another example being when predators were removed from areas with deer populations at which point the deer population exploded and did immense damage to surrounding forest land.  I don't know specifically the role sharks play in there environment, but it's almost certainly not how you think, Doggo Fitness.  Nature is all about finding equilibrium and that usually includes most, if not all, elements of it.  Just because you don't see it doesn't mean it's not there.

There are numerous sites that go into varying levels of detail on the importance of sharks, but here's one for a quick overview.  http://www.sharksavers.org/en/education/the-value-of-sharks/sharks-role-in-the-ocean/  And here's one that goes into a little more detail:  http://oceana.org/sites/default/files/reports/Predators_as_Prey_FINAL_FINAL1.pdf  I'm sure there are plenty from grade school introductory articles on up to post-graduate research papers.

Kaitlin mendes - I appreciate your incredibly strong feelings and the passion you have for animals, I feel that too. The majority of human beings do, actually, given that we're prone to empathy. However, just because something FEELS like it's the right thing, doesn't actually make it the right thing. Zoos and aquariums are vastly doing more good than harm for the animals. There are some species that have been hunted to extinction or near to extinction, which is a shame. However, your point of "Let's just not touch these animals anymore" lacks good reasoning. The fact of the matter is that we interact with our world as species. In massive ways, some good, some horrible. The climate changes may very well lead to many more species becoming threatened/endangered, and zoos/aquariums are the saving grace for such species. All you would be accomplishing with your universal theme would be the end of thousands of species that we could have saved.

See that's not even what's happening here. While it's true that great white sharks are at risk, it's hardly because of aquariums. It's because fishermen exploit them for their valuable fins - that is the root cause of this problem.  Aquariums taking in great white sharks is really not exploitative - the idea of aquariums taking in species at risk is that we can keep the species alive, while using the profits from the aquarium to support that. The issue with this, when it comes to great white sharks, is that they fundamentally cannot be kept captive - they just cannot live in such an enclosed space. This is a problem, because fundamentally, if we can't keep an animal in captivity, we can do nothing to help it. Our attempts to solve the root cause - exploitative fishermen - are completely unsuccessful. This is a story of the painful realisation that there is nothing we can do for the great white shark but hope.
Maiaxx .

It's been shown that, when children are exposed to an animal whose wild populations are threatened, they are more likely to care and take action and support conservation causes when they're older. The greatest example of this is in the case of orcas.  If we 'leave them alone', we risk having a population that feels disconnected and apathetic to endangered animals, and the longer that continues, the less likely that population will support or do anything for conservation efforts when they're really needed.  So as sad as it is that some sharks died in these attempts, the time that they were in those tanks, and little kids excited about them got to see them, in the flesh, swimming around, means that we'll have people passionate about helping them down the line.  If you look at it with a longer timescale, efforts like these just make sense.

When my daughter was little, her favourite movie was Finding Nemo. And like most kids that age, we watched it every day, day after day, and she never got tired of it. It sparked an interest in marine life for her, so we went to our city zoo which includes a few small tropical aquariums, and she saw and learned about the clownfish, the moorish idol, the cleaner shrimps, and others. (also the pelicans elsewhere in the park. lol) The rest of the fish we looked up at the library, where I helped her find the books with the best pictures and read interesting facts about sharks, rays, and anglerfish. She enjoyed this just as much if not more than seeing the live fish in an aquarium.  Having knowlegeable researchers go out into the sea and capture great whites on film in their natural habitat is all we need. Most kids don't need to see them in person, and if they really want to badly enough, encourage them to grow up to be marine biologists

Animals are never endangered because people try to catch them to place on display, as there's only a few thousand zoos worldwide - only hundreds that will even attempt to keep a difficult exotic animal with little documented positive experience. They're endangered because their habitat is destroyed by commercial activity, because they accidentally get injured by manmade objects and machinery that wasn't intended to catch them at all, or because they're poached illegally for food or 'valuable' body parts.  So it appears that trying to regulate what is on display isn't going to contribute to solving the problem, it's more like closing the eyes and pretending the problem didn't exist. Instead you need to raise awareness, investigate, and combat each specific root cause on a case by case basis.  A better argument is that since we can't figure out how to store and display these specific animals without injuring them and causing them painful death, it's inhumane to do so. But then it's debatable whether we should care about that short term, or whether accepting an occasional sacrifice on the path of figuring out how to breed and restore populations is a reasonable compromise.

Tabatha Taylor okay well keep in mind zoos have changed dramatically since the past hundred years. If you go to any state zoo today you'll notice thats its not just a purpose of entertainment. Alot and alot more to follow have been highly renovated for the animals comfort and space. The zoos today empathize detailed conservation, hazards to the various species, and education about them. Alot of the animals are rescues from many various reasons. It's not all perfect but alot of the people that work to take care of them do love and care the best them they can. And for the animals well being, for one they are not complicated creatures like us. Not even close at all. The don't feel, express, or desire the way we do. They eat, sleep, socialize/not, mate, repeat. Different animals do need allotted space but generally speaking zoos can and have offered it well. As long as their needs to survive and thrive are fulfilled they'll be good. An elephant doesn't look past his/her enclosure and think about what the worlds like out there or what outer space is like. An elephant learns from his/her mother to survive and continue on. And that basically applies to most animals

Zoos are actually why a lot of animals aren't extinct. When the zoos are properly maintained and run the animals are actually very healthy and happy.  Melbourne zoo has some elephants and they're always having a ball. The keepers work very hard to give them new toys and plenty of stimulation.  Zoos are incredibly valuable to maintaining endangered animals. Without zoos many of your favourite animals would likely now be extinct. Breeding in captivity is what keeps tigers going, and pandas. Letting people see the animals is how they get funding.   Aquariums are different. Seaworld needs to die. Some aquariums only care about displaying the animals with no regard for their happiness and safety (like Shamu.) Zoos are more international and therefore the majority of them are properly monitored.  Many many zoos are properly accredited and are incredibly valuable. https://www.zoo.org.au/fighting-extinction  You might not like animals being put on display, but it's the best way to get the public involved and invested in wildlife conservation. The orangutans in particular get a lot of attention - there are sponsorship programs and signs and billboards encouraging people to get involved. I was there a few months ago and they were talking about switching to recycled toilet paper to save rainforests. Without our zoos many animals would be left in the cold.  And be honest - if you love animals, you're going to want to see them. This is how we get people passionate about conservation.

I can argue that my house is a literal prison, but then again, you would call that not living. Life is just life. All life is to wake up, hunt/gather, eat, move around, poop, pee, mate, sleep, and repeat the cycle until the day you die. The end.

+Tabatha Taylor Zoos and Aquariums have kept many endangered species from the brink of extinction, and sometimes even make the population of a species grow. It's more like an animal rehab center than a prison. Animals that have gone extinct, died off in the wild completely, while in captivity have survived up to 60 years longer. In most animal species, thats about 3 generations. Do some research before trying to be smart and self righteous. You don't even know the Monterey Bay Aquarium(the one that held the Great Whites) I've been there many times, and they usually release their animals that survive in the wild, and keep those that are unable to live in the wild. They just try to research and help the animals. Its a world renounced aquarium, that even I have been to multiple times. Stop trying to be a retarded PETA ripoff. They are just trying to educate the public on the organisms that live in the same environment. Monterey takes the animals right out of their own bay, no imports.

Grace Zhu and GojiraLegionnaire Zoos are not sanctuaries. Their sole purpose is profit, they hardly do anything for "educational purposes" either, especially considering the vast majority of people don't go to zoos to be educated. Zoos aren't a rehab center, they breed and sell their animals. Sanctuaries are the ones who are there for the wellbeing and rehabilitation of animals, they also have scheduled tours for education. They don't breed and sell animals for profit, they don't buy animals, and are active within professional breeding programs. They only take animals that they know they can provide a natural, quality life and enclosure for. 99% of zoos are horrible, living 3X your lifespan isn't a positive thing if you live an unnatural life and in a small enclosure for entertainment.

As a biologist who loves animals and has worked in zoos during my undergraduate years. zoos and aquariums are VERY important. and yes sometimes, in the process of learning about animal healthcare they make mistakes. the same way medicine made more mistakes over 150 years ago than they do now. Those who say we should bring people to nature instead of bringing nature to us, it's a good idea, but incredibly expensive and liable. The whole purpose of these establishments is to educate the public in a controlled environment, there's a whole world of research that goes on behind the walls of aquariums and museums that people don't know about. Having a controlled environment makes it easier to educate with very little limitations and makes it safer and more accessible. An outdoor nature reserve is just too far away for most people to afford or travel to.

Your argument has various flaws. First of all, you say there is nothing inherently superior about doing things the natural way. Which is a meaningless statement without some given framework of meaning. If one is to assume you meant there is nothing inherently superior about a life freely liven against a life liven in captivity then you obviously lacked that kind of experience in your life.   This opens a whole network of language we could dive into, is it immoral if a life liven in captivity never experienced a life freely liven?  Till what extend did one way of living benefits the shark? Do we look at just the individual shark or the shark as a species, it's gene pool?   Let's refer back to the superiority part of your argument. What do you mean by inherently superior? The only objective truth I could grasp from that box is a definition grounded by evolution. Which leads us to the shark's gene pool. This video left nothing to the imagination of whether this way of living holds an evolutionary advantage over the 'natural' way to live. So I think we could state that there definitely is something inherently superior about going the natural way. Btw inherently and natural point to the exact same things in this argument.  With this kind of reasoning you get nowhere. You will be left with the conclusion that there is no point in doing anything, so why not just die already. Which is fine, if it works for you.  However, as you state, we have a choice. So why choose one that annihilates consensus in morality? If you aren't completely fine by dying at this very moment then you should also consider all other life around you.

Stan van der Bend, you used a lot of words to say a lot of nothing.  What I meant was that arguing we should leave them in their natural habitat because it is their natural habitat is not a valid argument in and of itself, because something being natural is not the same as something being good. (the naturalistic argument).  Obviously the current tanks are inferior, due to, you know, killing them. but that doesn't make all tanks inferior, it just means our current tank design needs to be improved. unless you have an argument as for why all tanks are inferior (rather than specific tanks) to living in the wild that will remain true.  As to evolutionary advantage versus non: humans have killed millions of species, and we will likely go on to kill even more. our effect on the environment is undeniable, and the species that currently have the best chances of surviving in the future are those that we have a vested interest in keeping alive. for instance Dogs and Cows are almost certainly not going to go extinct before humans, because humans have a strong desire to keep them alive (as pets and food respectively).  So long as sharks exist only in the wild people are going to be less interested in keeping them alive, (after all it is easy to forget about something dying when you never see it in the first place) and they could easily go extinct, if we built tanks to keep them in not only would we be able to guarantee their survival easier but we would also be more likely to want to do that. (Both on the aquarium's end, since it helps make them money. and on the customer's end, since they now have more personal experience with Sharks and thus more reason to want to keep them alive).  I have no doubt that over the next millennia humanities impact on the planet will only grow, and I expect that within a couple thousand years life will cease to exist on the planet without direct human intervention. keeping them in tanks is one such form of intervention.  And even ignoring the future, currently people are keeping sharks in tanks regardless of the fact that they die in them. And the fewer people do so the greater the incentive to do it becomes (because people are still going to want to see sharks, so the people who do keep sharks in cages will get more clients who are willing to pay more money, per the laws of supply and demand), all my original comment suggested was a potential method of tank construction that would seem to resolve the issue of them dying will still allowing people to see them.
Wertsir Man you can live in a cage and have people stare at you all day like an animal if you want. I enjoy my freedom.

Well I was responding to the things u said in your second argument. The first part concerned something I consider as one of the most fundamental philosophical problems, when does something truly matter? Then, in the second part u make a rather big claim about inherited superiority. I was simply trying to say that it certainly does matter how we deal with other life around us.    Anyways on to your new comment. I agree with you that it is not a valid argument on itself, that is what I was pointing out in the first part of my comment. It's only valid within some framework of truth, one you did not setup.   Then u point out that natural and good are not the same kind of truths. Here we run into a moral issue, what is good and what is bad? This is also impossible to even approach without first making a set of presuppositions that fit within some framework of meaning.   I agree that the current tank designs are a fail. No one ever claimed this automatically flags all future designs as inferior to their natural habitat, neither does it automatically entail the design 'needs' to be improved. It seems likely they will be improved as long as there is economic gain in it. Obviously the reason why these tanks are so ill-designed is because the incentives are set for profit, not the well-being of the shark. These obviously have a relation to each other. When one increases, it is likely that so does the other. 99,9% of the species that ever lived are extinct. The species that are most likely to survive are the ones that best adapt to the environmental changes, there is no evidence that artificially keeping a species around is the best way for a species to remain.  Dogs, cows and sharks are both very different examples. Cows we keep because we need them for nutrition, dogs we keep because we need them for comfort and sharks we keep because we need them for entertainment.  All three examples are on a completely different peak on the moral landscape. There is no such evidence that this is the best way for them to live.   Dogs are what they are now because we like them that way, our society is designed to include certain pets. This is the best way for them to live now because this became their 'natural' way of living. The only assumption you'd have to accept is that pet dogs generally have a better life than street dogs.  Cows have been genetically altered by humans to produce more food, this is a more artificial way of living already. We basically grow the meat and keep it alive and well enough as to improve the product.  However, recent breakthroughs in technology, allows us to grow meat ourselves. Expected is that within a century the mass murder of animals will be over and meat production will be replaced by lab grown meat. What happens to the cows then? This points out that this way of living is too artificially constrained already to bear any direct evolutionary advantage.  An aquarium is not the only place where you can see a shark in action, there are a million other ways to reach people and bring awareness. Take this video as a prime example. And humans do not have to keep them alive, we do not have to do anything. It is what we should do what matters. So that is what we should question.  Ok?  I do doubt that actually. That prediction is of such complexity that one could impossibly use it to support an argument that is so zoomed in on this particular kind of possible intervention of extinction.  I never denied this, nor do I find myself lost in disillusion of this being a problem that is easy to tackle. My original comment was a response to your second comment, which I thought of being compressed to a point of being incomprehensible. Thus I extracted it's contents and tried to see what you were getting at.

I keep seeing hate for zoos in the comments, and I don't understand it at all. I can understand the hate for circuses and places like Seaworld that have had a history of treating animals inhumanely. Sure, if you go back in time, animals in zoos were kept in terrible conditions and we're just there to bring in money. But now, we can see so many zoos around the world are trying to create positive changes in the way we view animals. And so many of those zoos are actively trying to keep endangered species from going extinct. The San Diego Zoo in the US has so many programs for different species of endangered animals ranging from mammals, to amphibians, etc. That zoo has one of the largest DNA banks of endangered species DNA, so hypothetically if one species was to go extinct, then they could possibly bring them back. Zoos today are not what they used to be. In the past, the enclosures for animals were called cages. Now, we call them exhibits or something of the like. We shouldn't refer to them being in cages anymore because the zoos of today try their best to recreate the same environment that those animals would have lived in in their natural homes. We need to accept that, at one point in time zoos weren't good, and move on.  EDIT: Also, in the case of the Great White Shark, they should not be kept in captivity. Until scientists can truly understand why they die so soon in tanks, then they should try again. Spending so much money probably, on a cause that's not going to end well is a waste and it's not fair to the animal. When the scientific community can solve this problem, and can keep a white shark in a tank for an extended period of time with no problems, come back to me and I will probably have a different opinion on their capture.

Lydia Estrange  The brains of different animals are very different (some animals having no 'brain' at all) and subsequently have very different levels of intellect an emotional experiences While I would have thought it obvious that humans were more intelligent than animals (assuming you have not made up your own ethics based definition of 'intellect'), it is also widely accepted by nearly all biologists that simple animals like ants do not have the same emotional capacity as humans, and cannot feel many of the emotions we can, such as boredom. The same is true for practically all non-human animals, with a very few 'possible' exceptions. It is also worth noting that animals do not have the same needs and desires as people, with sharks, as a non-group based animal, not needing other sharks nearly so much as we long for social contact. In the case of very young children or mentally handicapped persons with very limited intellects or emotional capacities, these people would have families who love them and so much more that would complicate matters if they were to be put on display as an animal, hence we haven't had people kept in these conditions for over 100 years (this is ignoring the aforementioned additional needs of humans like social contact that would still leave this much worse for any human than a shark)

I volunteer at my local aquarium and I get this question ALL THE TIME. I don't blame people, just because I know they're asking out of curiosity and not because they're actually "stupid". I get things like why don't we have whales, dolphins, great whites, etc. The simple answer is, some of these animals need a very large amount of water to swim in along with lots of attention and others to play with while others just can't survive in captivity period. If you follow the AZA's rules, dolphins need a minimum of 1,000,000 gallons of water alone and some people don't realize just how much water that is. Fun fact: our local aquarium's largest tank is 385,000 gallons and it took 30 days just to fill it with water coming from a hose from a fire engine. That doesn't include mixing salt and other materials in it to make it appropriate for animals to live in folks!

Extra comment for those that want to read something a little funny. Like everyone else that has a job/volunteers, I get many stupid questions or hear ridiculous things. Just look up a picture of one and see how ridiculous some of those guesses are. My all time favorite will always be when an adult pointed to a star fish and asked me if it was a sea snake. Zoos and aquariums are great resources for studying living creatures. It allows researchers to watch how creatures respond to specific conditions and circumstances that cannot reliably be recreated (or without the risk of interference) on the field. It also allows scientists to do things like dissect specimens when they die of one cause or another, something that is far harder on the field because you have to hope a specimen happens to die while you just so happen to be very close by.  And thats just the raw scientific applications. That doesn't take into account conservation efforts and educational ventures undertaken by zoos. The public face helps to keep the lights on so that everything else behind the scenes can keep going.

I've spoken with marine biologists at the Monterey Bay Aquarium. They've opined what many people already suspected -- that great white sharks are apex ocean predators that need freedoms that cannot be replicated in a confined space.  They argued that it would be akin to taking a human being who loves to travel and explore and suddenly placing him or her into a 4 foot by 4 foot room with no internet, books or television. It doesn't matter that you would feed that person. What matters is that the person would eventually become effected by his or her enclosure.

That depends on what you're comparing. There are over 5,000 species of mammals, and Humans do fit into that category. However, to call humans animals is not accurate. There are many traits that Humans and Humans alone have that are not found in any other species on this plant. For instance, those sharks are not using tools or inventing anything new such as technology or philosophy. Those sharks are not using medicine (such as surgeries, or complicated diagnostic tests to determine ailments). All of those things are specifically human. And there are hundreds of more examples.  If you want to think of yourself as equal to sharks or other "animals" you are selling yourself short. Humans are miraculous in their abilities -- however, many of them choose to reduce themselves to the lowest common denominator. I am not discounting the beauty of "animals" nor am I discounting the majestic ability that those species possess. Keeping a shark like that is quite obviously extremely difficult (and costs us a lot of money) and I think people need to stop trying until we have better knowledge of the species and way more resources. Besides, the Japanese aquarium mentioned at the end of the video clearly took some backwards steps in solving the puzzle, it's pure conjecture of course but I don't think they actually had any new or innovative ideas, the shark died after a few days.

Making money off these animals (which tends to go to the animals' well being and conservation efforts) while teaching children about the planet they live on and encouraging conservation to protect these species. Absolutely crazy.

Jarynn I understand your perspective on this, however I just don't believe holding these animals captive, whether the money made is being invested back to them or not. Wild animals don't belong caged in any instance for the enjoyment of humans.

The alternative is for the rich to be able to trample into delicate ecosystems to see them themselves while average people will never get anything more than a dry documentary to see them through.  Does anything exist solely for the benefit of humans?

I don't know exactly how it is in the rest of the world, but where I live the main focus of the zoos nowadays is to help the animals. They're rescued animals, or they're endangered animals in breeding programs. Most zoos around the world co-operate and switch animals from time to time to prevent breeding between related animals. Zoos mostly rely on donations, but an audience can help with the costs.

I do not care to "win" this discussion but I am interested to discuss this subject with a fellow scientist student (Applied Biologie in my case. Dutch is my first language so forgive any mistakes in translation please).   Let me first state clearly that I've got love for all animals, chickens, giraffes and sharks alike. In my opinion they should all be treated with respect and be spared as much harm and suffering as possible. It is however difficult to spare an animal (or a ecologic system for that matter) if you do not understand it. In the early days of zoo's, people had no idea how to take care of wild animals. I was very sad to hear that many animals died by peoples ignorance.   Nowadays animals thrive in zoos, especially now laws (obligatory five freedoms of animal welfare and such) are getting better and better over the centuries. By letting zookeepers forging bonds with animals (in a way safe for both animals and people) gives us an opportunity to study the animals up close and learn exponentionally about them. With this knowledge we can educate people who may be harming animals by ignorance. Don't forget it wasn't too long ago people were convinced animals and babies don't feel pain but just have reflexes. And a lot of people are still convinced fish can't feel real pain because they can't express it. When people see animals up close, in real life, that sticks more to memory and heart than seeing them in a book. You can show a kid a picture of a lot of trees and tell it that it's a forest, but take it to forest and it will really understand. As a science student, of course your fascination lies with science but how did it start out? Did you immediately decided to be a biological scientist after you saw a picture in a book or did you go to a zoo or aquarium with school or your parents? Maybe the combination did the trick? Knowledge and appreciation come from experience and different insight on the same subject.   Knowledge about animals, animal welfare and animal health is not only educated to people in zoos but the knowledge is gained by zookeepers and scientist too in the zoo itself. We've come very far with succesfully keeping a lot of different species in captivity. Unfortunately, we haven't come as far with marine species yet. The ocean is for us a more unfamiliar place then the moon, or so I've heard. Although every death shark is as sad as any other death, as long as we try our hardest best to make it work (keep the shark alive and happy) and as long as we learn as much from failed attempts as we can, the death will never have been in vain. And that's why I personaly think that there Ã¡re good reasons ONLY under good circumstances, to take a wild healty shark from it's natural invironment: to study it, to educate people about it and to let them develop an appreciation for it, hopefully leading to a lifestyle where he or she makes an effort to contribute to the protection of the enviroment, just as what happened to me when my parents took me to the zoo for the first time.  I hope I gave you more insight to how I see matters as these. You don't have to agree with me but I do like your opinion on my view as I am writing an opiniated piece about it at the moment.

no offense but you did not address where are great white sharks cannot be kept in captivity other then for a short time. you failed to explain the reason other than saying the shark belong in the open ocean. as a kid I recalled watching a great white shark Special by Nova. where are young great white shark named Sandy was kept in a large circular tank in California in I believe was the early 80's and after 14 days had to let her go when she started bumping into certain spots of her tank what they found was there was a weak electrical fields at those points. now I may not have a doctorate in marine biology but it would be my guess giving the behavior of great white and given the fact they are a migratory shark and go to the same places every year. putting them in a tank impedes their ability to navigate in concordance to their life cycle. it's with that thought that makes me think that's why they had such success with REALLY young sharks. especially when considering the fact that the best of our knowledge when great white sharks are born they are already 5 foot was documented along the coast of California tend to stay there for 4 to 6 months while they grow to 7 to 8 foot long before swimming South towards Mexico. when there are 7 to 8 foot long they can compete with a bit more dominance with other predators. and let's face it after 30 to 40 years of "studying" them we still know VERY little about the great white shark.

Well, the question this video aimed to answer was "why GW sharks are not found in our aquariums," despite other species like nurse sharks doing fine. The video said the sharks don't eat.  So starvation/malnourishment.  And visible injuries from crashing into walls.

Because white sharks inhabit an open ocean environment, they rarely encounter situations in which they are stationary, so they never evolved the ability to pump water (oxygen) through their gills. Instead, they move in long straight paths to continuously circulate oxygen into their bloodstream. In fact, when they sleep they've been shown come up to shallower water to access a steady coastal current to swim against as they sleep.   When placed in a small habitat they not only have less open water to circulate oxygen, but they also have no access to currents and variable depths to provide adequate conditions to facilitate sleep.   Sharks in captivity very likely die from complications of lack of oxygen to the brain/other organs, which could include anything from a stroke to simple suffocation. But note that most of these sharks were not eating (which could be a hallmark of extreme stress, or other factors in environmental feeding cues we do not understand yet), so malnutrition cannot be overlooked.   Regardless of which stressor (or combination of stressors) killed them first, all of them endured a great amount of suffering during their time at these aquariums. We learn much more by visiting them in their homes rather than bringing them back to ours.  Hope that helps a bit :)
