An adult great whites are over 20 years old. That means that neurogenesis had enough time to produce a viable neural pathway that recognises and responds to ocean currents and EM field. You get that shark into a small (relatively) pool with various electronic devices around him and that shark will have a problem to adapt. The reason their health declines is they are essentially hypoxic.. the reason being, their sleep walking - breathing (long story) , is insufficient, and infact, to completely shut their nervous system requires some stationary time. they can only achieve this in the wild using a stationary current position. ergo, they remain still whilst their gills are facing a current. It took generations upon generations of keeping wild animals under the care of humans until they finally started to domesticate (Which continued to take a long time).   2) A lot of pets people have today aren't actually domesticated. Ignorance is not cute. If you care to research, Blackfish was proven fake and manipulated. They actually found employees who were fired so therefore vengeful. Also everyone interviewed had an extreme bias which destroys the purpose of having a "educational" documentary. If they want a real non biased film they would have interviewed sources who both agree and disagree and argue why. But they used ex employees and scientists who already had anti seaworld and anti captivity programs and agendas (some even worked with PETA) If you care to research the subject instead of blindly follow trends set by PETA (Who are far worse than seaworld btw) seaworld #1 has changed many of their programs including no more theatrical shows and now just educational ones. They have also stopped their breeding program. #2 seaworld also does so much to help wildlife. They are the #1 sea rescue program in the country but don't get the recognition they deserve. They are there for every ocean disaster like the BP oil spill where they saved over 100 endangered sea turtles all the way to a single injured animal like the young sea lion that was shot back in 2012. Also, Every new animal there is an injured animal determined by the GOVERNMENT not healthy enough or strong enough to be in the wild so seaworld takes them, and if they're able to, rehabilitate them so they can be put back in the ocean. If they are not able to and if the government agrees they won't survive without assistance then seaworld will take them and take very good care of them. It is important to have places like seaworld because so many species are becoming extinct or endangered and the only way to even have the possibility of taking them off that list is places like seaworld having those animals in case the government wants them to breed the species and release them to grow the population. Fun fact: there are actually a few animals at Animal Kingdom that don't even exist in the wild anymore so the only possibility of bringing them back is through the captive ones breeding. It's one thing to have an opinion but you better have real hard facts to back it up and not a single mockumentary. I also have many sources if you'd like me to link any. If you want to shut down seaworld, do not complain about how little help there is for injured sea life, ocean disasters, and endangered/extinct animals.

While they didn't say it explicitly, they kind of explained why. Firstly sharks need to be in constant motion  in order to breath, so when they are being transported by truck they don't have the oxygen flow they need to survive. Therefore many don't don't make passed transportation. Secondly, since sharks need constant motion in order to live that means sharks need a wide open habitat, something that an aquarium can't really give them. Thirdly sharks move fast, because of this they keep crashing in to walls and hurting themselves. Aquariums just can't keep great white sharks,because they can't recreate the conditions a shark needs to survive.

There are a lot of very insightful and close minded comments. The fact is, sharks are a vital species which provide many ecosystem services. They are declining in populations due to human activity. Like Briana Harter (from the comments) said, aquariums are used to study the different marine life and do promote marine life conservation. And like other comments have said as well, sharks are not the enemy. They might seem scary, but they rarely attack humans. Only about 6-10 deaths by shark attacks occur each year. In fact you're 30 times more likely to die from being struck by lightning than being killed by a shark. It's really important that we try to help protect marine animals and aquatic ecosystems because, you may not know it, but they provide many ecosystem services to earth and it's humans. Humans need to be more conscious of the choices they make or else we'll be a species who drove ourselves to our own extinction.

Great whites are used to roaming across a huge range, and no tank can give them that environment that they need. It is a variety of factors, such as hitting the glass too much, refusing to eat, and others mentioned in the video, but it's all tied to stress. It's kinda like how if you put a person in solitary confinement for a long time, they will come out totally broken. The shark though, can't survive the stress, and as you can see, even when a great white is released from captivity, the toll it has taken on their well-being is just too much to recover from.

+Ethan E I think you need to redefine what "emotions" are. So you say that trees do not have emotions? I can agree with you on that, but you said everything that moves got emotions. Trees move, most plants move, plants grow and lean towards sunlight. Grass produces a distress smell when something eats it or a human cuts it (the smell of newly cut grass), does that count as feelings? Venus fly traps eat insects and other creatures with meat on them, once something goes inside their mouth they either close their gap or starts to produce a disolving acid-like liquid to disolve the insects, venus fly traps are plants.  Emotions isn't based of if they move or not, it's based of their brain.  Fish and insect does not have the part of the brain to feel and plants doesn't have a brain at all, they simply have not evolved to do so. But plants, fish and insects will do anything to survive even if they do not have a brain or can't feel, because they have evolved to react to damages like this: "Oh an attack, let's do something with it so that I can survive and reproduce". While mammals have evolved like this: "Ouch, that really hurt, let's do something so that the pain will go away and make sure that this will traumatize me so that I make sure to never get in this situation again".

ya know, I see a lot of people here gone on their soap box about "leave the sharks alone" and "Why kill them to make money" May I take a moment to play Devil Advocate here? The intention of any of the captivity of these sharks isn't souly profits. Yes, people do want to come and see something like a Great White up close and person, and it's a rare enough occurrence in the wild that surprisingly few ever get to safely outside of the TV.  However, it's precisely because of the natural habits of sharks like Great Whites to constantly roam over huge expanses of Ocean that make the prospect of raising them in captivity so enticing from a scientific standpoint. It's hard, VERY hard to track the same shark when it literally makes the equivalent of cross country trips constantly in the vast ocean, it's also incredibly, STUPIDLY INCREDIBLY expensive to do so as well. As a result of those two factors, even today we still know incredibly little about these creatures beyond certain feeding habits and some migration patterns. We know next to nothing of any social structure between White Sharks, We know nothing of their breading habits or birthing habits, we don't have a firm grasp of how long they live, how long they can live till, how fast they grow, in truth we really don't know nearly as much about White Sharks as we'd like too. Yes, we DO know more then we use too, by a large margin, but there is still so much more we have yet to learn and the fact that finding a single shark repeatedly is like literally finding a needle in an ocean sized hay stack is making that research INCREDIBLY difficult and expensive, as in if you robbed EVERY disgustingly paid celebrate in the world, we'd still probably had money issues in this research.  So with that said, if we could raise them in captivity, that would be the holy grail for researchers. They could reliably study these creatures and learn about them, better our knowledge of them, and the more we learn, the better equipped we are at protecting the wild ones. If we learn how they breed, what factors play into it, we can ensure humans do not interfere in this. If we learn there they give birth, we can protect those places. The possibilities for what we can learn, and the good it does, are endless. So if it were possible to raise them from birth to natural death in captivity, well hell we might be able to make breathroughs with the super expensive research out in the wild.  So do keep that in mind before you go and demonize and crucify these scientists for wanting to be able to learn things that, to date, we do not know. Honestly learning more about Sharks like the Great White could prove not only useful in a scientific standpoint, but could actually save lives if we can learn what exactly prompts an attack, and can design measures to prevent them.

Zoo's and Aquariums are actually really important. These animals you say are dying because of natural selection? Well, most of them are actually dying because of you and me. They don't "love" the thrill of the hunt; that's anthropomorphizing a creature that functions almost purely on instinct. No predator enjoys hunting because every time they hunt, they risk injury. In the wild, if you're an injured predator, it's essentially a death sentence. It's why gouging at eyes of sharks will deter them â€” you're too much of a risk to hunt.  White Sharks have the physiology of a creature that's meant to aggressively hunt prey. Basically, since they're equipped with the tools to be aggressive, so that's how they'll be. It's similar to how terriers love to chase things, but also shake their heads to break the neck of whatever the catch â€” they need to end it quickly because the way they hunt is by chasing them down solo instead of being reliant on a pack.  As for them eating live prey: White sharks will scavenge, and will scavenge whenever they possible can. I mean, everybody's seen those videos of them having a feast on a whale carcass. They also get drawn in by chumming and baiting the waters for when people cage dive.  The most common fact of well sharks pick up the scent of blood just shows that sharks are drawn to prey that aren't necessarily 'their' hunt. This goes back to how predators always preferring the least risky way to not starve.  I understand what you're trying to say, and it's true that sharks belong in their natural habitat. But you shouldn't pepper that important message with information that isn't true.

Zoos are vile places. We should not put animals on display for the ogling eyes of the public. I haven't patronized a zoo in more than 20 years and I will never visit one again.  People should instead visit their local library and check out books about wildlife to learn as much as they can about the creatures with which we share this world; do even more research online; view nature programs on television; go see IMAX films dedicated to showcasing animals in the wild; and watch YouTube videos of people showing their chance encounters with animals where they're supposed to be... in the wild!  Give your money to conservation programs committed to preserving wild space for native populations. Dean Cutler If I said captivity was always bad for animals, I take that back. Snakes, for instance, absolutely thrive in captivity (I'd know, I have 3 pet snakes and they're in prime condition). What I'm saying is that in most instances though, an animal would do far better in a wildlife sanctuary instead of a zoo. That doesn't mean they wouldn't be able to be fine in a zoo, however.  With great whites, I think it's impossible for them to flourish in captivity, simply because of the reason they've died in captivity in the first place. By definition, captivity means the thing being captive isn't free to roam around wherever they wish, and again, since that's the reason great whites can't live in captivity in the first place.  But really it comes down to the animal, like I said. Using snakes as an example yet again, all they want is water, warmth, food, and shelter. Since humans can easily provide all of those, snakes typically thrive in captivity. As mentioned earlier with the great white however, we can't provide them with one of their most important requirements in captivity; freedom.

Sharks have to stay continuously moving in order to breathe right? Well in the ocean they are used to traveling linearly as far as they please and turning only as they please. I would imagine that it would be impossible for a shark to "sleep" or hibernate as it swims, like in the ocean, if  it constantly has to be alert enough to turn direction or it will slam into a wall which would still wake it up. It's a bit of a pity about this situation. People may give zoos and aquariums a lot of grief for keeping animals in cages and tanks, but they serve an important educational purpose to the general public, to see exotic animals up close, and gain a greater appreciation for the world's biodiversity. Without zoos, people would not understand these animals, and have less empathy for them in the wild.  This is especially critical for great white sharks, because their public image is still largely informed by movies and Shark Week, where they're depicted as "mindless eating machines." Hundreds of millions are killed every year, partly for shark fin soup, casualties of commercial fishing, or just because humans plain don't like them. By comparison, all species of sharks from 1958 to now, have attacked less than 3000 people, and killed less than 600. The amount of sharks we have killed in kind is incalculable.  So long as sharks continue to be seen as movie monsters, and only thrill-seekers in shark cages bother to see them, there's little reason to think this trend will change.

I'm no expert but I've always believe that many sea life creatures need to use their movement to both regulate body temperature as well has changes in water pressure. In order to keep a great white it would have to be a very young pup, then placed inside a tank the size of four football fields. There would also need to be a wave and current generator as well as constantly changing levels of salinity every so often. You would also need to regulate the temperature. Deeper level colder higher levels warmer. There is also food source. Young White's eat fish then move up to mammals. The problem there is that your would have to figure out if the pup was one of the Whites that eats a certain mammal. Seals. Keeping a group of seals in the tank for breeding and living would also be difficult. Because they would have their own needs and may need even more room, very likely the tanks would need to be 6 to 8 football fields in size along with sand, rocks, and beach material. The cost would be ridiculously high.

What's funny is how many of us berate this aquarium for attempting to keep great whites, despite it finally giving up on trying to keep them in captivity, while not acknowledging that, a) the research found was only because they figured out a way to keep them alive for more than a few days and, b) that the sharks were harming themselves because of their instincts for roaming. Concerned about the well being of these animals? Then lets play a game of looking at the bigger picture. Have you all ever heard of a fish known as the coelacanth? Two species of coelacanth are currently recognized to be around still, one believed to have a population of 500 max. Furthermore, coelacanths, as I understand, are currently considered the most critically endangered class of animals currently. Now, for those of you who understand the scale of the ocean, you'll realize 500 makes the whole "meet, greet, breed." thing a little difficult to do, even in a small portion of it. If nothing is done, they very likely would go extinct on their own from this alone.  So you might react "why not breed them in captivity?". Well, as I understand, we've never been able to keep a coelacanth alive in captivity. If this is starting to sound familiar, then it should. It seems until recently, very little information was available on coelacanths to the public, and it was just recently a lot of our understandings of them have changed. We still have a lot to learn about them, and how they potentially effect the environment, yet they're close to disappearing. Yes, we're partially to blame for this, but its also "too late to fix it" because trying to take them into captivity is likely to just kill them, and we don't even know if they'll breed in captivity. And there have, as I'm sure many of you recognize, been examples of captive breeding keeping species within existence.  And you have to remember, at the end of the day, most of our research on marine biology, which has done a lot of good, ends up occurring outside of the oceans.

I'm a HUGE shark fan and I always have been, despite living in Kentucky where access to them is limited to television....and the occasional aquarium.  I have avoided watching this video because the answer to the question is not new to me.  Going back into my childhood in the 80s, I've known why White sharks aren't in aquariums--they die. They get sores from circling the tanks against the walls. This is something I've known nearly all of my life. This is why I'm only now watching this video tho it popped up for me more than a week ago.  I'm a little curious how this understanding of Great Whites was lost. How can a landlubber in a landlocked state know this information and have it seem such a mystery to professionals?  That isn't a brag; it's a genuine question. I'm no one and I knew that part of the story...I don't think I can believe that professionals didn't.

If you can't or won't do something right, then IMO don't do it at all. It is completely possible to house this shark, and most fish, in captivity safely. BUT, the housing conditions needed for large open water predatory fish are too expensive for most organizations, and so large that it would make observation almost impossible. Could you imagine looking for a single fish in a tank that was a thousand feet tall and several miles long & wide? As with most predatory fish, they are highly sensitive to slight water changes, but their diet requires food which will in fact cause water parameter shifts that can be lethal...aquarium enthusiasts with delicate 6-inch fish in a 230+ gallon tank can spend $5,000-10,000+ on filtration, so poor sharky needs filtration on a scale that probably only Bill Gates can afford....just to give him some non-toxic wuddah, never mind all the other factors that need to be accounted for!!! The more logical way to go about this is building aquariums that are underwater observatories to view sharks in the wild or very large man-made & controlled bodies of water. These fish require space that is impractical for an artificial tank, and if you can't provide a fishy with a reasonable quality of life then it's time to reconsider the game plan.

That's why we're trying so hard to do so. The marine biologists involved in these efforts care more about the creature than you or most others (myself included) ever could, they've devoted their professional lives to the understanding and betterment of these creatures - obviously they don't want them to die. I'm not even going to tackle your false analogy with human experimentation, it's so moronic it would take paragraphs to dissect (no pun intended). I know you're well meaning, but spreading this sort of rhetoric only serves to hinder, not help. Lack of understanding is the only sickness humanity suffers from.

+MaxsSeveredHead, We know very little about a lot of things. For example - the human brain. Many in our species suffer from degenerative brain diseases. In a similar case with most organs, a transplant is a plausible cure to the illness. But not for the brain. Brain transplants have not been done on humans yet and we are unsure whether it would even be possible. It leaves in limbo so many questions in regards to memory storage, transfer of information, neurologically networks and the brain's overall relationship to the human anatomy. But we haven't tested it on a living human being and most likely won't in the near future.  I'm certain marine biologists care about the well-being of the animals, but I am also certain that researchers are hungry for information and will push as far as possible to gain knowledge. As a researcher, I can definitely relate to that sentiment. However, in our pursuit of knowledge, humans can at times overstep ethical boundaries, and since ethics is mostly a differing moral norm laid down by an individual cluster of people, overstepping for "the greater good" can ostensibly be appealing to scientists. Hence, the Institutional Review Board (for humans) and Committee on Animal Research and Ethics (for animals) was set up to make sure research is done ethically. Because animals cannot provide consent for a study or fight off human interference in habitat modification, it is essential that ethical researchers do not impose a study that greatly disrupts the population of a certain non-human life form; especially one that might be endangered.  Do we know enough about the benefits of studying the Carcharodon carcharias because prior studies have led to the deaths and puny information gained from such investments. Bertrand Russell exemplified this point further in the 'Theory of Knowledge' stating that true beliefs do not constitute knowledge until their truth becomes self-evident. The truth of a belief may become self-evident if its truth is evident without the need for any demonstration which is based on the evidence of other beliefs. According to Russell, knowledge is based on acquaintance with self-evident truths. True propositions which are not self-evident may have to be demonstrated to be true by self-evident propositions in order to become objects of knowledge. Knowledge is based on acquaintance with self-evident propositions and with propositions whose truth can be demonstrated by self-evident propositions.  I fail to see how these concerns are "moronic" and since you don't care to elaborate on the point, I suggest initiating a dignified discussion or disengaging altogether. I don't care for sardonic statements about what I don't understand if you're not going to make an effort and present alternative viewpoints.

What this video doesn't do a good job at illustrating is that the Monterey Bay Aquarium is not only an aquarium, but also a world class marine institution. From keeping animals in captivity they've not only been able to generate enourmous interest in marine preservation, but they have also learned a lot of valuable information that has helped with restoration. Nearly single handed my they've revived the California is Sea Otter population from a colony of just 150 otters, to a much healthier number. As a not for profit institution, I think it's safe to say their intentions were to learn more about how to protect the sharks, rather than grab money.

+bob8065 why do most of the animals there die way earlier than the usual death rate using that factor? And multiple crashing their heads against the glass multiple times in a row for periods of time.

bob8065 no, fish and insects have nervous systems therefore they feel pain. There have been multiple studies showing this. Kai'a Bellamy Nervous system =/= the ability to feel pain. A nervous system at the very least is something that makes a living being move. +bob8065 wow thats condescending. I am actually a student doing my degree in biological and ecological sciences so cheers for the assumption that I'm not educated in the subject. Obviously that is why the fear factor evolved but how it evolved is different, if you do some research on the subject you will find multiple studies showing that fish are a lot smarter than you seem to think and that they, along with cephalopods like octopuses and squids, do have the ability to react to harmful stimuli that we would call 'painful'. They do have very different brains to us and so maybe they feel something different but analogous to our pain.

I had to read about that a little. It does say it's not known if they feel pain or not. They lack most of the parts of the brain that humans and mammals have that note pain, but it's not known if fish feel (are conscious) of pain. But they do react to pain and injury. And at least in humans it is vital to be able to feel pain. Humans that are born unable to feel pain often die within 5 years (I think it was, I could be wrong with the time). Because feeling and reacting to pain is one very important part to stay alive. If you don't feel pain, you don't remove yourself from it, meaning you might take too much damage and die. Fear is another very important thing to have to live. More important than pain, but still. But also remember that for most animals, especially animals that are not living in packs or herds, showing that you are in pain may equal death as predators will target you first. Many animals hide their pain until it's so bad they simply cannot. I have seen a horse with a deep chest wound, not blinking an eye about it. Not because it didn't hurt, but because it's a prey animal, and they don't show pain for natural fear of predators. I think fish feel pain. But they are very unlike humans, and we might not ever fully understand them. And they probably hide their pain as well.

Good point.Â  I had a dog a few years ago that was seriously ill, but never showed it until it was too late.Â  A kidney infection that could have been healed proved fatal because she never showed any discomfort or pain.Â  She broke my heart.

Rescue and rehabilitation nonprofit organisations do release animals but most, if not all, zoos are for-profit organisations which do a great job raising awareness and funds for conservation but do not directly increase wild populations by reintroducing animals back into the wild.

Well I wasn't going to reply to your comment but now I read that you seem to actually believe that Great White Sharks dying would actually be good for us. I hope you are just joking but in case you are not then I'll respond. If the Great White Sharks suddenly went extinct it would probably create a massive imbalance in the oceans ecosystem (Specifically the food chain) which would most likely affect us humans in a negative way. They eat several things like sea lion, seals, turtles, rays, many types of fish, etc. If they don't eat them it might lead to overpopulation of many if not all of these animals. Thus more of these animals will be hunting their preys and that would most likely lead to a massive reduction if not extinction of said prey animal species. And as in a chain reaction it can come to affect us all (humans and other animals) negatively in one way or another. Thus Great White Sharks dying most likely isn't a positive thing for us. If someone is afraid of dying or losing a limb from a shark they most likely have the choice of not going into ocean waters, especially those were Great White Sharks are known to frequent. Same with the horse and cows, you can probably avoid them. Now did you know that around 3000 people die each year (Give or take) from choking on food? This isn't a lost limb like with sharks, this is a definitive death. What would you suggest in the case of choking? Do we stop eating? And what about car accidents and deaths? Should we stop using them? These are risks we decide to take because, generally the benefits far outweigh the risks.   Btw, they also eat carrion which would makes them a big part of the ocean waste cleaning crew E.I. Keeps the oceans cleaner. If they are gone, who is going to eat those massive whale carcasses if not them? You and me perhaps lol? I don't have much of an appetite for them though so I think I'll pass.

Did you learn nothing from Jaws 3? :P  Seriously though the problem is that if you built an underwater park somewhere, there'd be no guarantee that the visitors would see anything. Somedays there would be no significant marine life around. So people would complain about being ripped off. At least with an aquarium you have guaranteed attractions (not that I agree at all with keeping animals captive).  So there would be a strong incentive to try to keep the big attractions (like sharks and whales) around, perhaps by leaving out food for them. But that would disrupt the ecosystem, forcing competing and hunter/prey species together for the amusement of visitors. That could be even more disruptive to the environment.  Best solution; remove completely this fascination with zoos and aquariums from our culture which only dates back to the 19th century. We can use drones and VR instead.

To an extent I can agree with you there, it's a primitive ideology living in a world that's progressing past those standards. But there is some value, in that zoo exhibits can be used to raise awareness. In the Seattle-Tacoma area of Washington state for example, they have one of the only displays of the nearly extinct red wolf, which that zoo made great efforts to save in a program they headed. Thanks to coyotes and overly territorial humans, they can barely survive in the wild, but thanks to this program there's still a chance of their continued survival in the natural world where they belong.

Zoos not only raise awareness, but are really important places for research on animals and also in captive breeding programs that can help save endangered populations (the California Condor, for example, was completely saved through the efforts of the San Diego and LA Zoos).  Sadly these programs need funding, hence they put out some animals on display and have people pay for the zoos, but a great deal of work is done behind the scenes in learning about the diets, behavior, biology, and ecology of the species they hold.  Researching by tracking wild species is incredibly limited in the amount of information you can gather; just think about how hard it is to find a single shark in the ocean (and the cost of the excursions by boat needed for every sampling/research trip), nevermind documenting their diet, movements, sleeping and mating habits, and how they give birth/care for their young; the amount of information we can gather from observation in the wild is totally eclipsed by the amount of information we can gain from a captive specimen in a much shorter period of time.  It's often cruel/unkind to that one captive specimen, but the knowledge gained greatly helps our understanding and hopefully future efforts to help the rest of that species.

I believe that some species of animals can (and should) be put on display in zoos. However, only those animals that can fair well in captivity and lead completely safe, enjoyable lives. Saying "no animals should be kept in captivity" is illogical, as A: many animals can fare very well in captivity, and B: it allows people to see/experience and learn about animals that they would normally never see.   Fish and inshore shark species are a great example of animals that can fare well in captivity and still lead happy lives. So can penguins, otters, etc. But animals like pelagic sharks, dolphins, orcas, etc, do not fare well. In the case of the sharks, they usually die very quickly after being put in captivity. And in the case of the dolphins and orcas, they can live in captivity, however, they are extremely intelligent and social animals - almost on a human level. And they have been shown to become extremely bored and even develop depression in some cases (dolphins have even been known to commit suicide).   So here is the TL;DR version: many animals can be kept in aquariums and still lead happy, healthy lives. However, other animals cannot. So we should only keep animals that we know can survive well in captivity.

Not with humans in the mix... we catch 70 million sharks a year for the shark fin trade. Having predatory sharks in captivity allows people to get up close to them and connect with them without the historical negative stigmas toward sharks. The white sharks that the Aquarium displayed was the world's first successful attempt to do this with the MOST stigmatized species of shark, and probably any aquatic animal. It doesn't have anything to do with whether or not animals are "safer" in captivity, but that the aquarium and zoo industry does not affect wild populations of animals as there are literally a handful of such accredited institutions in comparison to wild populations, no matter the vulnerable status of a species. The Monterey Bay Aquarium displays fish and invertebrates that are all caught in the food industry or aren't and therefore not vulnerable in the wild, and also rehabilitated birds and sea otters, the latter of which participate in surrogate programs for otters that can be re-released.

Aquariums functionally serve for education and conservation purposes. Unlike say, Seaworld, which is entirely for profit, most Aquariums function on grants and donations as opposed to admition fees, and mainly go to great lengths to attain specimens to raise public awareness as well as for research purposes. Many also serve as rehabilitation faculties for injured animals before they get reintroduced into the wild. As it points out, many aquariums went to great lengths to try to keep the sharks alive and healthy.

The question though was whether scientists believe humans have evolved over time or stayed in the same form they are currently in since the existence of humanity. Evolving over time as a human is reasonable and expected in 1 form or another.  However, my point is to whether humans (and other species as well) evolved into what we are today from an entirely different species. The theory suggests all species ultimately evolved from 1 extremely simple organism over a very long period of time. The questions was not about whether we evolved from 1 organism entirely unrelated to what we are today. Dale Couture while I will admit the language is a bit ambiguous, "â€œhumans and other living things have existed in their present form since the beginning of time.â€" in this case "present form" is referring to species, in a somewhat ambiguous manner because the changes are subtle and the line for speciation is when the two groups are no longer able to reproduce, something that is often hard to draw a conclusion on while looking at evidence with now extinct species. Note the options were "evolved over time" or "existed in present form since beginning," the text somewhat muddles this. Also I am aware of Darwin's skepticism, we have come a long ways, hence why its not called Darwinism.

Individual self-regulations for off-springs will not help, the issue must be addressed on a grander scale to take effect. If the goal is to alleviate the stress we cause on the earth, population control is a solution but also a compromise in that it limits our way of life. Increasing resource yield is a better solution that can alleviate the stress we put on earth given that it is done efficiently. Imagine if there were no farms but 7 billion people still existed (completely hypothetical) We would hunt and fish until there's nothing left. But Agriculture and Farming allowed us to increase the output for food,which allowed us to preserve much of nature, and allowed us the time to be more than just hunters and gatherers so that we could achieve all that we have achieved. THAT is a solution. Because of farming and agriculture billions of humans can exist without hunting and fishing the world to oblivion.  Even now breakthroughs are being made that can help this issue. Cells can be grown into resource we can use. Just as you and I grow by cells multiplying, it is now possible to grow cells into the resource we usually kill an animal for... their meat and leather. The cells do just as it would do but without creating the conscious life that are humans and animals. it's also less wasteful as billions of animals solely grown for slaughter create an enormous amt of waste. Growing just the meat of an animal prevents all waste.  Efficiency and resourcefulness is the way to solve this problem. Imagine a world where the presence of human life actually enriches the earth instead of destroying it. These types of solutions take time and great visionaries to get just right. Animals are not on the same rank as humans. they are less important to us than our own kind much like how we rank lower to monkeys than their fellow species. It would protect me and I would protect it. As simple as that. As for wild animals, they act instinctively, many times not knowing what they did. They too have this idea of reciprocal interest, they may have mistaken us as another one of their type and saved us thinking it was saving its own kind. It has a moral system within it own species, albeit a different kind to ours. And just to clarify, those two types of moralities are incompatible. Here in Townsville we have a few of the Port Jackson sharks, a few hammer heads, a few Grey Nurse sharks, a few swordfish, several black tip reef sharks, a few manta rays and a few Tiger sharks but they're anywhere between 1/3rd to 2/3rds the size of a great white. Great Whites are apex marine predators and biologists are somewhat miffed about these sharks since they're rather elusive and that makes them hard to study, they've only started tagging them within the last 20 or so years and dissected a few dozen specimens but so much intel gets you only so far.

The adult probably died from lack of sleep, fatigue.  They have to stay in motion to keep water flowing over the gills.  The Great White does this while sleeping by achieving a slow downward dive that goes down several hundred feet deep before it gets too cold and the GW comes up to warm water and repeats.  That can't happen in a tank and the GW can't sleep, so when it does fall asleep from fatigue it can't jeep water flowing over gills and it dies.
JUST LEAVE THEM ALONE.

The reason they die is because great whites need a current or some sort of flow going through them at all times in order to create oxygen. When great white sharks sleep in the ocean they sort of turn on an autopilot mode in their bodies to keep their tail moving at all times. When you're asleep you obviously have no visual sensors so they hit the walls in their sleep because they need to be constantly moving, eventually causing them to die from lack of sleep.

Research, Conservation, and Education. By keeping animals in captivity, we are able to monitor them and learn more than we could in an uncontrolled environment like the wild. By keeping potentially threatened species in a controlled environment, we can ensure their species's survival and eventual reintroduction into the wild. And by having the animals up close, it gives people a better appreciation for the world around them and parts of the world they may never see. If you grew up in a city, the closest thing to wildlife you'd ever see is a pigeon. In your mind, it would always be that thing you read about, not something real and personal.

ranerk inasa Ideally, yes.. But lets take the sharks, for an example. No, we don't have the technology to watch a shark endlessly in the wild. Our ability to watch sharks generally involves stalking it in scuba diving gear, thus disrupting its environment and potentially tainting observations.  Zoos have also been used to save species that otherwise would have vanished. Zoos are able to keep endangered species in a protected environment where they can work to rebuild the population in a controlled manner and eventually reintroduce them into the wild.  Yes, orca life expectancy drops in captivity. Our ability to handle large marine wildlife, as spoken in this video, is still a work in progress. But most animals live far longer in captivity and live far healthier lives. A well maintained zoo will provide all the environmental and social requirements an animal requires while allowing education, conservation, and research to go on.  You also cannot overstate the importance of outreach. Zoos help connect people to nature. They are emissaries for the conservationists on the field, bringing the discoveries back home and raising money and interest to keep these projects going.

I totally agree with you, there are some zoos that are only there for profit and there are some that don't take proper care of the animals. But if you think about it, keeping an animal in an enclosure where they have access to food and water, proper social interaction with other animals and a spacious enclosure with surroundings fit for the species is much easier for an animal to live in than in the wild, where they have to compete for survival with other animals and risk their life (sometimes) hunting. Except things like zoos are actually really good for animal populations. An animal might not be able to live in the wild due to any number of factors in their environment and instead of just letting them die like you're suggesting they create a sustainable environment in an enclosure at a zoo for that animal to survive, breed and continue the life of that animal specify.   Sure this is a different situation but with advancements in putting Great White Sharks into aquariums we could potentially see something similar with Great White Sharks to help combat the dwindling population. A few may die now but isn't that worth it when you can potentially save the entire specifies? It also opens up more ways of researching the animal, because currently we know an incredibly small amount about sharks in general. +EndlessMike a half life implies the time taken for 1/2 the carbon to decay. after one half life we have 1/2 the original radioactive carbon. after two half lives we have 1/4 of the original radioactive carbon. therefore the quantity of carbon never becomes zero, only a smaller and smaller fraction. hence by measuring the quantity of radioactive carbon, comparing it to current day levels and math, we can use a 5000 year half life to measure 300 million years

If you really are curious there are a lot of ways they date fossils. carbon dating is one, but not 100% accurate if you go back far enough. Another way is to see where it fits relative to other fossils ( like an older fossil will have traits that are diminished in later fossils, and completely absent in today animals). You can also tell by what kind of rock the fossil was found in (the age of the rock would be about the age of the fossil). There are other methods too.

One major technique is radiocarbon dating. Essentially, a small but notable percentage of carbon on Earth is radioactive. Living animals keep this percentage around the same as the global average, but when they die, it starts decaying. When scientists find a fossil, they can run tests on it to determine the level of radioactive carbon still in it, and, knowing the rate of decay of this type of radioactive carbon, produce a rough estimate of when the creature died.

The same way they know a basic timeline of the existence of most living creatures, even many that went extinct long before we humans came into being, fossils. When animals die we leave remains behind, most of which decomposes relatively quickly under usual conditions except the mineral-rich bones and teeth. Through the fossil record scientists can tell a lot about history such as that some high mountain ranges were once oceans home to a plethora of sea creature species that haven't existed for millions of years.   They have a particularly hard time studying the fossil record of sharks since most of their structural makeup is cartilage and not bones, they do however have teeth they leave behind. I don't pretend to know how carbon dating or the other methods scientists use work, but I also don't know the ins and outs of oral surgery. Just because we don't understand how everything works doesn't mean smarter people out there who have studied things way more than us are wrong. Fossils just tell us that sharks lived in the past. They don't tell us when. For that you have to look at either carbon dating the bones or dating the sedimentary rock that the fossil is found in. Interesting enough, we still find Carbon 14 in fossils even though it has a half life of only about 50,000 years which actually implies that the bones were fossilized much much sooner than millions of years ago. As for dating the rocks, most of that dating actually using the assumption of uniformity, that sediments were laid down at the same speed for the past hundreds of millions of years. That is a huge assumption because we all know there can be periods of intense erosion during storms, volcanoes, earthquakes, etc. The empirical evidence for sharks roaming the earth 300 million years ago is slim.

People who say "Evolution is just a THEORY" don't understand the meaning of the word "theory" as it's used in science.  Scientists use "theory" to describe a process in Nature and then attempt to verify that theory with evidence.  If the evidence isn't sufficient, then the theory is modified or even discarded and a new theory supported by physical observation takes its place.  "But evolution is only a THEORY!" Well, gravity is only a THEORY and yet here we are, feet firmly planted on the Earth.  If you want to test the theory of gravity, jump off the roof of your house and remember to yell "IT'S ONLY A THEORY!" as you flap your arms.  Good luck with that.

Carbon dating only works for things up to around 50,000 years.  Anything older than that they have to date rock samples found in and around the sedimentary layer the fossils are found in using things like uranium-238, uranium-235 and potassium-40 isotope levels.

This is pretty easy, actually. See, we have a definition of "monkey" (ah, "Haplorhine primates" if you want to get technical - it's a type of nasal structure) that states a certain series of descriptive characteristics in skull structures, growth patterns of bone and muscle, methods of interacting with the world, and types of integument, and humans share all of these descriptive features - as well as a few more which allow us to also identify humans as the only current extant hominines, though we have a well-documented fossil record that contains thousands of individuals of tens of species of other hominines which are, sadly, no longer with us.  Humans are hominids - part of a clade that includes chimps, bonobos, gorillas, and orangutans. Like them, we are catarrhines, with nostrils that point down. Like all primates, we are mammals, and like all mammals, we are tetrapoidal chordates. The evidence (not proof, proofs are for math) that we are descended from monkeys is that we're monkeys right now.

+Drake Takeshi (Smash Killer) "Just prove how this planet was made in a big bang."  This is an unfortunate misconception -- the Big Bang did not make the Earth.  The Earth formed from the leftover gas and dust from the collapse of the cloud that formed the Sun; this was nearly 9 billion years after the Big Bang.  As for "proof":  we can date the oldest rocks on Earth, and date meteorites, etc., and we find that they are slightly younger than the Sun.  We can also observe the formation of other solar systems in star-forming regions.  "Tell me where these elements were made ..."  Essentially all elements except hydrogen and some helium were made in the interiors of stars that later exploded, spreading these heavy elements into space where they became part of the cloud that formed the Sun and the planets.  "... how come no other bangs can make something than rubble ..."  This is a part of the misconception above.

DerEchteBold Can't argue with that logic, it is definitely hypocritical to complain about animal cruelty when I am contributing to animal cruelty on a mass scale by eating meat, living in a house (animal habitat displacement), wearing clothes etc. Completely agree - and yet, those are all things that benefit me, if I had a digital alternative that would satisfy me just as well or benefit me even more, then I would switch to that - that's my argument against zoos and safaris and aquariums (actually I think safaris are quite cool) - my argument is that as time goes on and internet/HD video is more ubiquitous, it makes less and less sense to have zoos. It's not a great argument, but certainly one that can circumvent the hypocrisy, at least that's how I read it.

Also, it should be noted that I made the comment to let off some steam, just as people yell at their T.V, and it's a sentiment that people seem to get behind, but I didn't make it as a well-prepared, fully-fledged, debate-level argument, and I certainly did not make the comment with the expectation of having to defend myself. The comment is only an exaggerated extension of my actual rational feelings, it's my emotional reaction to these failed attempts at humans trying so hard to cage white sharks. You are more than welcome to poke holes in it, and you might make some valid objections, it wouldn't surprise me.

Animals species are dying in the wild at incredibly high rates. If we just rely on seeing videos and photos of animals eventually we're all going to be seeing videos and photos of an extinct species. By putting "animals in cages" it allows us to put those animals into a stable environment where they can live, which will prolong that animals life and potentially allow that animal to breed with other animals from its species to repopulate the world with that species again. It also opens up more avenues of research on the particular animal allowing us to better understand the animal and potentially understanding what it is in particular that is causing their extinction and we can use that information to reverse that extinction and repopulate the planet with that animal. It may be an uneasy thing for some people to understand but by "imprisoning innocent animals" we can protect that animals species from extinction.
+Nathan Evans (RoyalAviator) You make it sound like all human 'care' for animals is taking place in purely benevolent institutions with only more than holy motives. This is very unlikely the case.

In an age when the internet didn't exist, the only ways to educate people were through word of mouth, books, or illustrations. So when it came to public interest in learning about animals and the creatures around us, these were the only real ways to learn. However, these methods were limited in scope and potential by a variety of factors. Transmission speed was slow - books take a while to print and distribute. Update-ability was low - revising books and illustrations take long times. Reliability was also often in question - out of date books are not that useful, and word of mouth can be easily corrupted by human memory fading. Thus, enter the concept of zoos, aquariums, and circuses, where real people can see real animals in real time. The idea and novelty of being able to see an animal you've never seen before and probably will rarely see in your lifetime drove the profitability of these businesses. Why see an animal through the lens of an illustrator, author, or storyteller if you can just see it for yourself in first-person? Then, the internet came, and today, we have massive, easily accessible, and fast database of information that is constantly cross-checked and cross-reviewed by others on the internet. It takes the best parts of speech, books, and images, combines them, and makes the result into something greater than the sum of its parts. The advent of video also plays a large role too, and you can see the animals not just captured poses, but in real action. By adding the dimension of time to our graphical records of animals, we are able to see so much more about animals - not just how they look, but also how they act. The internet in turn makes all of this material on animals easily distributable and accessible. The end result is that today, we can learn lots about animals without ever seeing them in person, and also being sure that what we learn second-hand is reliable information in most cases. Because of this, we now see less need for zoos, aquariums, and circuses, and instead see the negative qualities that made these businesses possible and feasible in the first place. What it boils down to is this: at first, people were willing to ignore the bad things about zoos and aquariums in exchange for the opportunity to learn a few things about animals in first-person (not least of which is, what do they actually look like?), but now, we don't need zoos anymore, so their negative features become more evident. With lower demand for something comes a higher scrutiny of why such a thing exists in the first place.

Part of the problem lies in the fact that Great Whites believe that anything in the water with them is food. The other inhabitants of their tanks are just fresh snacks. Plus having their snouts bumped by the tank walls throws off their ability to track the motion and placement of their prey. Sharks often locate prey through sensing the natural electric currents in living bodies.   Also, I think the Great White has a different feeding pattern. I think that they tend to gorge quickly, taking very large, fast bites. I don't think an aquarium can accommodate a Great White's appetite. No wonder the poor things don't last. Their nutrition needs can't be met.

May or may not have anything to do with it. Sharks are primitive, they've lived for centuries & thrived in a natural habitat of the wide open seas. Compare it to dolphins, or other mammals like primates, they can adapt to their environment -- some find it more difficult to adjust of course but that's why many of them grow up & live in captivity because most who grew up in the wild generally can't cope with walls or barriers -- and as an extension animals & mammals that grow up in captivity on the opposite end of the spectrum, don't know how to survive in the wild due to dependency, the only reason a Great White was able to last & live long enough before they were released were only able to survive for a short while even after having been reintroduced back into the ocean. Which brings up the point made in this video about certain sharks seeming to adjust better in captivity than Great Whites because they were able to recreate their natural habitat, typically smaller sharks.

I'll just reply to all of you. Having animals in zoos is actually quite important- they raise awareness for their species. If you never saw an animals such as a lion, or tiger growing up why would you ever care about them? You have to be exposed to these animals first before deciding what to do about it, yes?  Before you scream 'murder, 'torture' or 'kidnapping', which is all ridiculous, think about it. A tiger doesn't think the same way you do, you can't apply human terms to something non-human, they're two unequal things. They don't have rational thoughts like a person does, and don't feel the same way about things you find 'terrible'.  However, that's not an excuse for zoos that don't properly take care of their animals and those few should be dealt with accordingly. All care standards must always be met, and when they are, the animals are quite content as ambassadors of their species.   And btw, tons of orcas are dying off the coast right now, but I guess since they're in the wild they don't matter as much as the few being taken care of at seaworld?

nonprofit zoos and aquariums are facilities for habitat and conservation research, and the display factor is a large reason why so much of that research is able to sustain funding. often, research needs to be done before an adequate sanctuary can be made for certain species. animals that have decreased quality of living shouldn't be kept needlessly, but the vast majority either live relatively similar lives or are kept out of necessity for vital conservation and genetic research.

also, animal sanctuaries often have the same issues with small gene pools and lack of breeding due to altered environment.  in general, more data needs to be collected to find reliable information about what can be done for endangered animals, but they are most certainly not being kept on display for entertainment. that's just... irrational.

Michael Consolo A giraffe doesn't need to be caged up and put on display in freezing Ohio, dumbass. If you're going preserve an animal, how about you give it the roaming space it needs. There's a reason why animals in captivity die earlier than those compared to animals in the wild. Sanctuaries and zoos are two COMPLETELY different things. If it's a rare animal, it's most likely endangered, where it belongs in a SANCTUARY in a habitat that has the roaming space and weather adequately similar to their natural one.

A. Lampman Not all zoos are permanent prisons; there are quite some of them that also double as a resting sanctuary for injured animals that need to heal up and are eventually released.  There also some that are conservatories that protect endangered species from full extinction by keeping it where it can easily be monitored and reproduce enough that it can eventually be released into the wilds again in the future.  Some zoos also work with researchers and biologists to research more about the creatures and thus provide better care and nutrition or at least monitor them better in the wild.

I'm not going to sit here and defend zoos and aquariums ruthlessly, because obviously they are by no means perfect places, and it is clearly wrong to keep particular animal species captive. However, for those denouncing zoos and aquariums and condemning them, I'd simply like you to (1). prove that they have not aided at all in conservation efforts, and (2). propose an alternate solution to how we can help save wild animal populations?  One thing is obvious - a lot of wild animal species have gone extinct in the past because of our actions, and a great lot of them are going to go extinct in the future, regardless of what we do. However, just leaving all wild animals alone and letting them be clearly wouldn't help them. It isn't helping them now.  I am not saying by any means that I support the capturing of wild animals to display in captive settings, or even the displaying of captive-bred animals that inherently live in the wild. (I'm also not saying that we should continue to try and make accommodations for species that simply don't fare well in captivity - if sharks keep dying in captivity, yes, leave them be, they're clearly not meant for that life.) But I am tired of people vilifying zoos when they have helped with conservation. No zoo is without its faults, and there are clearly zoos out there that really are prisons, but to say that every single one is and should be shut down is just overly-cynical and false.  I hate to say this, but the state of the environment and wild animal populations as a whole has become so poor that keeping certain animals captive is almost necessary today. I really wish that wasn't true, but I implore those of you to offer feasible solutions as to how we can fight this mass extinction without zoos and aquariums.

A lot of folks here seems to think MBA is SeaWorld. It's not. MBA is a non-profit conservation and research aquarium. It is run and funded by scientists, like its sister organization MBARI (which also deals with conservation and ocean exploration). It is not an animal circus like SeaWorld. It does not keep whales or dolphins or any other mammals (except for sea otters which acclimate very well to captivity). The only reason they kept great white sharks in the first place was to study them for conservation purposes. Which is why they are released after only a few months back into the wild.

Slavery was the systematic exploitation of an entire race. Zoos hold maybe a few hundred non-intelligent animals in captivity, where they are fed and cared for. Because humans have sentience in the sense that they are self conscious, have an emotion system and have long-term as well as short-term intelligence. Slavery was also far more brutal and acted with discriminatory values. It is also considered immoral to commit crimes against your fellow species simply from an evolutionary point of view i.e. cannibalism. No animal apart from chimpanzees and some whales have the brain adaptions to have the necessary rights, as other animals either are unaffected in their reality as they dont feel negative emotion, dont recognise themselves as an entity or have this long term intelligence in which they can consider the future and are therefore indifferent apart from pain reception that we often sympathise with as we place our human perception of reality onto them.

There is no such thing as a truly inherent or, as you put it, divine right. We made up these rights and they exist because we want them to. They exist because if some try to take them, people fight for them. They exist because we will them to. That being said, it is completely up humanity as a collective and as individuals to decide who and what they apply to. I believe we have the right to use animals to our advantage, however I think they should be truly to our advantage. The other sharks that the MB aquarium have reintroduced into the wild, along with many other large fish that they keep (sunfish, being a primary example) as well as orphaned & rehabilitated sea otters, have often no problems readjusting to a wild environment. The last white shark was the last for a reason - it made it clear that their regular system of collection-release wouldn't be worth it. So, really, don't jump to conclusions about a process and institution that you know little about.

Most of those sharks were accidentally caught. All of them are kept in the Monterey Bay Aquarium for only a few months. None of them were ever planned to be permanent residents. The research aim of MBA itself is to understand great whites more so they are better protected in the wild. The paradox of conservation is that you can not help something if you do not know how to help them. And finding that out can incur necessary harm.

From what I understand of the animal world sometimes animals won't adjust to different environments. I'm not against zoos or marine parks but here it seems like they're playing with chance hoping to squeeze as much as they can.

TheFlowMind Again, you are making the assumption that the Monterey Bay Aquarium is doing this for money. MBA is a non-profit organization. They do what they do for conservation and research, as well as outreach. It is run by scientists, not by corporations or entertainment executives. 2/3rds of their workforce are volunteers, and they don't keep whales or dolphins or any large mammals.  MBA is also the sister organization of MBARI. Another non-profit dedicated to conservation, research, and oceanographic exploration, famous for their deep sea ROV submarines. The latter is one of the most respected scientific organizations in the world, and can be characterized as the NASA of the deep sea.  Moreover don't anthropomorphize animals by assuming they want freedom like humans do. The vast majority of animals live in very tiny environments, and they acclimate very well to captivity. As long as it resembles their natural habitat closely enough, they will usually thrive far better than in the wild.  It is usually only with larger animals that captivity becomes more problematic. But sometimes it is unavoidable in the interests of preventing them from going extinct in the first place.  That is the case here with great white sharks. Despite having multiple movies made about them, we actually know very little about them in real life. To conserve them, we must understand them first.  Sure, places like SeaWorld are horrible. But not all zoos and aquaria are there to exploit animals. Some are there to help.

In an age when the internet didn't exist, the only ways to educate people were through word of mouth, books, or illustrations. So when it came to public interest in learning about animals and the creatures around us, these were the only real ways to learn. However, these methods were limited in scope and potential by a variety of factors. Transmission speed was slow - books take a while to print and distribute. Update-ability was low - revising books and illustrations take long times. Reliability was also often in question - out of date books are not that useful, and word of mouth can be easily corrupted by human memory fading. Thus, enter the concept of zoos, aquariums, and circuses, where real people can see real animals in real time. The idea and novelty of being able to see an animal you've never seen before and probably will rarely see in your lifetime drove the profitability of these businesses. Why see an animal through the lens of an illustrator, author, or storyteller if you can just see it for yourself in first-person? Then, the internet came, and today, we have massive, easily accessible, and fast database of information that is constantly cross-checked and cross-reviewed by others on the internet. It takes the best parts of speech, books, and images, combines them, and makes the result into something greater than the sum of its parts. The advent of video also plays a large role too, and you can see the animals not just captured poses, but in real action. By adding the dimension of time to our graphical records of animals, we are able to see so much more about animals - not just how they look, but also how they act. The internet in turn makes all of this material on animals easily distributable and accessible. The end result is that today, we can learn lots about animals without ever seeing them in person, and also being sure that what we learn second-hand is reliable information in most cases. Because of this, we now see less need for zoos, aquariums, and circuses, and instead see the negative qualities that made these businesses possible and feasible in the first place. What it boils down to is this: at first, people were willing to ignore the bad things about zoos and aquariums in exchange for the opportunity to learn a few things about animals in first-person (not least of which is, what do they actually look like?), but now, we don't need zoos anymore, so their negative features become more evident. With lower demand for something comes a higher scrutiny of why such a thing exists in the first place.

Life can be pretty good for the herbivores in the right zoo.  Not having predators to eat you and your young helps improve life expectancy.
Animals with injures, especially human caused animals or threatened species having to deal with human problems and predators. So basicly, you see a recovery breeding program from far away.

As I've said elsewhere, MBA is a non-profit conservation and research aquarium. It is not an animal circus like SeaWorld. And no. Not all zoos and aquaria are "prisons". A lot of animals today actually survive only in zoos. They'd have long gone extinct if not for them. Breeding and repopulation programs are important, as well as research. They aren't always magically better off in the wild, especially if their natural habitats are already gone in the first place.  The only real problems arise when it comes to zoos and aquaria which are built solely for profit or to entertain. In which case, you'll see animals being forced to perform or kept in horrible conditions that don't remotely resemble their wild habitats.
Angreh Kittunz The voice of reason, thank you.
+Angreh Kittunz thank you for telling it how it is.  I agree fully!

Some Zoos (called Zoos but are actually more like reserves and sanctuaries) do help some species of animals, especially herbivores who are close to extinction and other smaller species. The sad thing is, people don't go to zoos to see bugs and smaller creatures, they want to see exiting species, but unfortunately those species aren't meant for Zoos. Some animals who've lived in captivity all their lives and are rescued though are often put in safer zoos/sanctuaries because they simply cannot survive in the wild. I'm ok with seeing that, because with the money you give those non-profit sanctuaries they can improve the lives of the animals who live there. But animals who CAN survive in the wild, should be LEFT in the wild. :)

South Africa does it right. In Gaans Bai in the so-called 'shark alley', you are taken out in a shark-viewing boat, with cages attached to the sides. You get into the cage, dive in a wet suit, but without scuba tanks so as to not disturb the sharks with the additional noise. So it all boils down to you being able to hold your breath and wait. During the seal season a large number of great whies congregate there for food and mating.  The sharks are attracted via chumming, but are NOT fed from the boats, so that they do not associate boats with food. Instead, they are drawn towards the seal rocks which make up shark alley.  I had the privilege of seeing a 3.5 meter great white give a test bite into the lower right corner of our cage. It was the most exhiliarating, humbling, thrilling, but also eye-opening encounter I ever had with live, wild animals. My respect, as well as my concern for the well-being of these amazing creatures grew enormously.

Simply, its because great whites are used to moving huge distances in the open ocean; they can't cope with small spaces - they just stop eating properly and get stressed, or damage themselves because they keep swimming into the glass walls. Also, adult great whites feed on aquatic mammals like seals and sea lions etc. - thus their dietary needs cannot be met in captivity anyway, which is why they can only really keep young ones in the first place.   Nurse sharks, lemon sharks, and other types of sharks that live in coral reefs seem to be able to live in captivity, the larger ocean-going sharks, like the great white, cannot cope. The reason for this is because these smaller reef sharks spend their lives in the same reef and don't move great distances in the wild, so they can cope with staying in one area. Also a coral reef is easy to replicate; and since their diet is fish, their dietary needs can be sustained in captivity. Whereas, the bigger ocean-going sharks like the great whites are itinerant, and wander the oceans all over the world, swimming thousands of miles. Their natural habitat therefore is not replicable because they need huge areas to roam, and in the wild they transition between different habitats as they wander around.  Their impulse is to wander huge distances freely; they can't cope in confined spaces. In comparison, smaller sharks naturally stay in the same reef so can cope with being confined to one area, unlike the larger ocean-going sharks like the great white.

Kyle W Research a bit into breeding marine organisms, its not as simple as it sounds. For many organisms you need the right lighting, and the right temperature, and the right salinity, and the right phosphates and calcium and this and that.  Lighting can easily tell us what time of the day, or if its only during the blue spectrum then we know they breed at deep water.   Salinity can easily tell us where in the ocean they breed, near the coastal inlets or in the middle of the ocean with the highest salinity.  Phosphates can allow us yet agian to know where in the world they breed. In the gulfs where nutrients stack up or in the open ocean.  Calcium same thing, and so on and so forth.  By knowing these things for other organisms such as oysters, shrimp, fish, etc, we have learned so much in their life in a such quicker amount of time. We can also track them, however that's far more expensive and far longer then learning from them in captivity. The following 3 things I listed help us know exactly where they breed. However that's just a sliver of information we get when we keep organisms in captivity.

Actually zoos and aquariums contribute to the conservation of endangered species pretty significantly. Considering most private foundations don't have the funding nor the staff to put together solid breeding programs, zoos and aquariums are essential. The spectator aspect is a major downside and contributes greatly to discomfort and stress of the animals, but without that there would be no money to care for them. I don't believe that you have a full understanding of what's going on in the "natural" world that you believe to be so perfectly suited for all the animals, but with human activity being so dense and evident, zoos and aquariums are more than likely a good thing, despite the fact that it's not an all-around safe haven.

Zoos have research programs that help expand our knowledge about animals, especially theÂ endangered species. The information gained by these programs can help protect, and treat the species in the wild, as well as determine what affects if any climate change may have on the regions needed for the species to flourish. Many zoos also have breeding programs for all kinds of species, endangered or not, and learn even more about the species during the breeding, and rearing process. All this knowledge and information is shared with visitors, organizations, and other programs alike. There are certainly zoos that do nothing but display animals, but so many have broadened their exhibit goals, and expanded their species scope of responsibility, that each zoo really needs to be judged on it's own merits.
